<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/2XdbYggQ-c0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZxWXCT9wVoI" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>






*Priority Sector lending in India has been made a salient feature of the banking in India mainly due to the social and economic objectives that underlie PSL.
*However, banks are also required to keep certain amount to maintain [[Statutory Liquidity Ratio]] (SLR) and from the remaining disposable amount, 40 per cent is dedicated for the priority sector.
*Thus, large fraction of banks’ resources cause the so called ''Double Repression'' on the banking system.
*The 2014-15 Economic Survey has brought this issue to the forefront and has recommended the government to re-structure SLR and Priority Sector Lending.






*Drought has an extensive meaning and can be defined in many ways. For example, it can be defined as a condition of prolonged climatic dryness that is severe enough to reduce the soil moisture below the level necessary for sustenance of plants, animals and human life.
*Out of the total geographical area of India, almost 1/6 area with 12% of the population is drought prone; the areas that receive an annual rainfall up to 60 cm are the most prone. Worst drought hit state is Rajasthan with 11 drought affected districts including Jaisalmer as the driest district.
*Droughts can be of three kinds --
''Meteorological drought''

*This happens when the actual rainfall in an area is significantly less than the climatological mean of that area. The country as a whole may have a normal monsoon, but different meteorological districts and sub-divisions can have below normal rainfall.
*The rainfall categories for smaller areas are defined by their deviation from a meteorological area's normal rainfall --
| Excess| 20 % or more above normal |
| Normal | 19 % above normal to 19 % below normal |
| Deficient | 20 % below normal to 59 % below normal |
| Scanty | 60 % or more below normal |
''Hydrological drought''

*A marked depletion of surface water causing very low stream flow and drying of lakes, rivers and reservoirs.
''Agricultural drought''

*Inadequate soil moisture resulting in acute crop stress and fall in agricultural productivity.
----
<<<
:EARLIER YEARS OF ALL-INDIA DROUGHT -- 1987, 1979, 1972.
<<<
----
!!!Causes of drought
''Environmental''

*El Nino and heat waves. El Nino plays significant role in deciding the monsoon in India like prolonged breaks in monsoon, late onset and early with drawl of monsoon.
''Impact of ENSO and LNSO on Indian monsoon''

*Positive Indian ocean dipole events are associated with El Nino --
**Warmer sea surface temperatures in the western Indian Ocean relative to the east.
**Easterly wind anomalies across the Indian Ocean and less cloudiness to Australia's northwest.
**Weakens the Hadley cell and pushes rain bearing clouds away from the Indian subcontinent.
**Less rainfall over Indian sub-continent, southern Australia and the Top End.
**Thus El Nino causes droughts.
*Negative Indian Ocean dipole events are associated with La Nina:
**Cooler sea surface temperatures in the western Indian Ocean relative to the east.
**Winds become more westerly, bringing increased cloudiness to India, Australia's northwest. 
**Strengthens the south west trade winds and Hadley cell.
**More rainfall in the India, Top and southern Australia.
**La Nina may lead to floods the countries that surround the Indian Ocean basin. 
*Re-establishment of southern branch of jet stream. 
----
<<<
*In the recent forecast it is estimated that India will have a good monsoon with rainfall likely to be 106% of the long period average (lpa) of 89cm.
*Underlying optimistic reasons for this are:
**Waning of El Nino (Positive Indian Ocean Dipole).
**Setting in of La Nina phenomenon( Negative Indian ocean dipole) .
**Indian Ocean dipole -- the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is defined by the difference in sea surface temperature between two areas (or poles, hence a dipole) – a western pole in the Arabian Sea (western Indian Ocean) and an eastern pole in the eastern Indian Ocean south of Indonesia.
<<<
----
''Artificial or Man-made''

*Large scale deforestation.
*Use of HYV seeds and intensive agriculture.
*Excessive pumping of ground water.
*Increasing water pollution due to release of industrial effluents into water bodies and making them unfit for consumption.
*Lack of irrigation facilities lead to agricultural drought.
!!!Impacts of drought
*Reduced soil moisture leading to increase in area of fallow and barren land.
*Loss of livelihood.
*Unemployment.
*Migration of people to other areas.
*Decline in agricultural productivity.
*Food inflation.
*Food scarcity and starvation leading to malnutrition, which further adds more burden on economy.
*Scarcity of drinking water, fodder.
*Loss of habitat to marine species.
*Disappearance of bio diversity.
*Low morale of people, increased suicides of farmers and deaths due to starvation.
!!!Measures to mitigate drought and its impact:
*Afforestation.
*Reducing water pollution.
*Making use of sea water through RO in coastal areas.
*Artificial methods to recharge groundwater and rain water harvesting.
*Early and efficient prediction (block wise division of land for enhanced prediction) of drought like situations by extending the use of remote sensing and GIS data to warn the farmers of its impact.
*Encouraging the use of organic manure which can help the soil sustain mild droughts because of its moisture retaining capacity.
*Providing alternate employment to farmers in case of severe drought.
*Reducing water wastage in abundant areas and diverting that water to drought prone zones through interlinking of rivers.
*Proper implementation of drought and flood related schemes to transfer its benefits to the needy on time.
*Robust mitigating measures should be taken by govt to combat water scarcity in urban areas. (Tamilnadu govt made it mandatory for every household in the state to construct an overhead tank)
----
<<<
''Drought Prone Areas in India''

*Extreme Drought Prone Areas -- parts of Rajasthan to west of the Aravali hills, Kachchh region of Gujarat.
*Severe Drought Prone Areas -- Eastern Rajasthan, Most of Madhya Pradesh, eastern part of Maharashtra, interior part of Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Telangana Plateau, Northern part of interior Tamil Nadu, Southern Jharkhand and interior Odisha.
*Moderate Drought Prone Areas -- Northern Rajasthan, Haryana, Southern Uttar Pradesh, and remaining parts of Gujarat and Maharashtra, some regions of Tamil Nadu and Karnataka.
*Free or Less Prone Areas -- remaining parts of the country.
<<<
----
!!!Recent Developments
*Recently, IMD has replaced the word //drought// with ''Deficient year/Large deficient year''. 
| [img[http://www.livemint.com/r/LiveMint/Period1/2016/01/08/Photos/w-drought.jpg]] |<|
| !Positives | !Negatives |
| It now includes mild to severe water scarcity zones (means large area covered). | Many state governments are ignoring the new classification as they are feeling the 10% less than normal rainfall’s impact is not significant. |
| Helps in taking measures early when the scarcity is mild. | States are not accepting their failure in mitigating its impact and so are not approaching centre to avail benefits. It means State’s problem is hidden. |
| More farmers can be covered under benefit schemes like [[MGNREGA|Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005]] for employment. | Increased fund allocation leads to increased corruption and less transfer of employment benefits to [[MGNREGA|Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005]]. |
| Helps in ranking state’s performance in ensuring the welfare of its people. |  |
!!!Recent measures taken by the Government
*The Centre, in September 2015, raised the employment guaranteed under the scheme from 100 days a year to 150 days in drought-hit areas.






*In November 2014 the Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA) facility became operational for citizens (unless they are of Pakistani origin) of over 40 (presently 113) eligible countries, including those who are eligible for visa on arrival.
*ETA is issued for tourism, visiting friends and family, short duration medical treatment and business visits. The scheme was renamed to e-Tourist Visa (eTV). 
*An application for e-Tourist Visa must be made at least four days in advance of the date of arrival. Visa is valid for a single entry with a maximum stay of 30 days from the date of arrival and can be obtained twice in a calendar year and cannot be extended.
*Persons who ever held Pakistani citizenship, or who have a parent or spouse that held Pakistani citizenship are ineligible for India's new E-Visa scheme, and so must apply to their local Indian mission for visas.
[img[http://www.simplydecoded.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Visa-free-India.png]]






*Vitrification is a cutting edge technology for cryopreservation of embryos (blastocyst stage also) and eggs. Earlier slow freeze method was used to preserve embryos and eggs. 
''Slow freeze method''

*Embryos were run through different solutions of media to dehydrate the cells and replace it with cryoprotectant (glycerol, Dimethyl sulfoxide DMSO are generally used).
*Later they were labeled and packed in straws, which were put in freezers.
*These freezers slowly at -0.3ͦ C per minute, cool down the embryos to -35 degree C using liquid nitrogen.
*They are then stored in liquid nitrogen (-165 degree).
*Cellular activity will be thwarted at such low temperatures and thus remain viable.
*Crystallization of embryos takes place because of sufficient time to rearrange the water.
''Vitrification''

*The water molecules in an embryo are removed and replaced with a higher concentration of cryoprotectant than in the slow freeze method.
*The embryos are then plunged directly into liquid nitrogen(-165 degree). This drastic freezing creates a glass transition temperature, commonly called a “glass” state, and the embryos are vitrified. 
*This quick freezing reduces the chance for intercellular and intracellular ice crystals to be formed, thus decreasing the degeneration of cells upon thawing for embryo transfer.
----
<<<
''Note''

*Eggs have more water than embryos hence they suffer intracellular crystallization.
<<<
----






*Bharat Stage is based on European norms
*Auto-fuel policy 2025-Saumitra Chaudhari Committee recommendations 2014
**BS-V in all over india by 2019 and BS-VI in all four wheelers by 2023
**stringent lead and sulfur emission standards-BS-V,VI (10ppm) have a fifth sulfur of BS-IV fuel(50PPM)
**sulfur blocks catalytic converter and lead blocks particulate filter of exhaust system
**india already produces lead free petrol from 2000
**producing such clean fuel a challenge for indian refineries, because most them have old equipments eg north eastern refineries like digboi Numali Garh, Bongaigaon, Guwahati
| !Respirable Suspended Particulate Matter standards |<|
| BS-I | 0.14 |
| BS-II | 0.08 |
| BS-III | 0.05 |
| BS-IV | 0.025 |
| BS-V | 0.005 |
| BS-VI | 0.0025 |
----
''Note''

*Expenses increase with stringent norms
*Cetane number -- denotes the percentage (by volume) of cetane in combustible mixture of cetane and 1-methylnapthalene whose ignition charaterictics match the diesel being tested; higher the number easier to start the engine
*Octane number -- denotes the perventage of octane in a combustible mixture of iso-octane and n-heptane whose anti-knocking propersties match the to the petrol being tested; higher the number, less knocking; lead is anti-knocking agent.
----






*241st report of the Law Commission stated that passive euthanasia should be allowed with certain safeguards and there was a proposed law, Medical Treatment of Terminally Ill Patient (Protection of Patients and Medical Practioners) Bill, 2006.
*There are three types of euthanasia, positive, passive and living Will:
**Positive Euthanasia-when the medical professionals, or another person, deliberately do something that causes the patient to die.(capital punishment)
**Passive Euthanasia-Passive euthanasia occurs when the patient dies because the medical professionals either don't do something necessary to keep the patient alive, or when they stop doing something that is keeping the patient alive like switch off life-support machines, disconnect a feeding tube etc
**Living will Euthanasia-in which a person makes an advance declaration that if during his treatment, it becomes clear that there is no chance of revival, he should not be put on life support system or ventilator
*In Aruna Shaunbaug Case SC in 2011 held that that the right to live with dignity will be inclusive of the right to die with dignity, but the judgement did not arrive at a conclusion on validity of euthanasia
*GoI is fine tuning the proposed bill, but it will not legislate on Active euthanisa since there are more chances of misuse and few countries worlwide use it. Passive euthanasia will be in the law in spirit of SC 2011 judgment.






*This piece of equipment is essential to the work of Air Crash Investigators as it records the many different operating functions of a plane all at once, such as the time, altitude, airspeed and direction the plane is heading.
*Modern Flight Data Recorders are able to monitor countless other actions undertaken by the plane, such as the movement of individual flaps on the wings, auto-pilot and fuel gauge.
 






*Geo-textile is defined as any permeable textile material that is used with foundation, soil, rock earth et to increase stability and decrease wind and water erosion
*Have been used from Pharoah's time during construction of roads
*Made of synthetic polymer(polypropylene,polyester,polyethylenes and polyamides) or natural-synthetic composite polymer.
*Applications
**Civil engineering applications-Roads, airfields, railroads, embankments, retaining structures, reservoirs, canals etc
**Sand Dune Armoring- Geo-textile sand filled units to protect upland coastal properties from storm surge, wave action and  floods.
**Geo-textiles have been used ot protect homonid footprint fossils of Lateoli, Tanzania from erosion, rain and tree roots.
**Stabilization of slopes when quickly establishing vegetation is not possible.
**Natural geo-textiles of coir and jute can be used to establish vegetation, since these degrade into humus and provide eroosion blanket of 2-3 and 1-2 years respectively
**Coir and jute are especially useful in contaning wind erosion. Can be used in Chambal badlands, Thar etc.






!!Handcrafts:

!!!Srikalahasthi Kalamkari and Machilipatnam Kalamkari:
Kalamkari or Qalamkari is a type of hand-painted or block-printed cotton textile. The word is derived from the Persian words ghalam (pen) and kari (craftmanship). There are two distinctive styles of kalamkari art in India - one, the Srikalahasti style and the other, the Machilipatnam style of art. In ancient times, groups of singers, musicians and painters, called chitrakattis, moved village to village to tell the village dwellers, the great stories of Hindu mythology. Progressively, during the course of history, they illustrated their accounts using large bolts of canvas painted on the spot with rudimentary means and dyes extracted from plants. Thus,the first Kalamkari had been born. In the same way, one found in the Hindu temples large panels of Kalamkari depicting the episodes of Indian mythology, akin to the stained glasses of the Christian cathedrals.

Srikalahasthi Kalamkari :

The Srikalahasti style of Kalamkari, wherein the "kalam" or pen is used for free hand drawing of the subject and filling in the colours, is entirely hand worked. This style flowered around temples and their patronage and so had an almost religious identity - scrolls, temple hangings, chariot banners and the like, depicted deities and scenes taken from the great Hindu epics - Ramayana. Mahabarata, Puranas and the mythological classics. This style owes its present status to Smt. Kamaladevi Chattopadhayay who popularized the art as the first Chairperson of the All India Handicrafts Board. Only natural dyes are used in Kalamkari and it involves seventeen painstaking steps.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/98/Brooklyn_Museum_-_Wall_Hanging_%28Kalamkari%29_-_overall.jpg]]

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/54/Kalamkari_Painting.JPG]]

Machilipatnam Kalamkari:

The Machilipatnam Kalamkari craft made at Pedana near by Machilipatnam in Krishna district, Andhra Pradesh, evolved with patronage of the Mughals and the Golconda sultanate. It mainly uses vegetable dyes which are applied onto the fabric with the help of wooden blocks.

[img[http://c8.alamy.com/comp/AC6MK4/kalamkari-prints-machlipatnam-andhra-pradesh-AC6MK4.jpg]]

!!!Kondapalli Bommalu

This art of crafting is 400 years old. Kondapalli Bommallu are the toys made from soft wood in Kondapalli of Krishna district, a village nearby Vijayawada in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.
 The wood is first carved out and then the edges are smooth finished. The later step involves coloring with either oil and water-colours or vegetable dyes and enamel paints are applied based on the type of the toys which fall under three distinct categories:
*animals and birds
*male and female figures depicting rural life
*mythological figures

[img[http://www.thehindu.com/multimedia/dynamic/01776/03VJTAN01-KONDA_04_1776423e.jpg]]

[img[http://blog.whatsuphyderabad.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/kondapalli-toys.jpg]]

!!!Budhiti Bell and Brass Craft:
The Budithi Brassware originated from a small village called Budithi in Srikakulam, a district in A.P.
Black and gold rings are the unique features of this product. Locally available, non- toxic black powder is the base for the effect.

[img[http://www.travel-andhrapradesh.com/images/hbundi.jpg]]

[img[http://www.lepakshihandicrafts.gov.in/upload-images/Lep-017-large.jpg]]

[img[http://www.andhraportal.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/budithibox.jpg]]

!!!Andhra Pradesh Leather Puppetry:

Leather shadow puppetry of Andhra Pradesh is known as Tholu Bommalata, (Tholu – leather, Bommalata – puppet dance). Two other kinds of shadow puppetry are practiced in Andhra Pradesh, but the leather puppets, because of their transparency and jewel like glow, are most popular.

The leather puppet, which was traditionally crafted from deer skin, is made from goat hide now. But apart from the translucency and vivid colours, what gives these puppets their brilliance, is the perforated designs drawn on the characters to depict jewellery. Once surrounded by colour and viewed against the light, they look like glowing jewels.

[img[http://blog.gaatha.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/02/leather-puppets1.jpg]]

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Hanuman_and_Ravana_in_Tholu_Bommalata%2C_the_shadow_puppet_tradition_of_Andhra_Pradesh%2C_India.JPG/800px-Hanuman_and_Ravana_in_Tholu_Bommalata%2C_the_shadow_puppet_tradition_of_Andhra_Pradesh%2C_India.JPG]]

!!!Uppada Jamdani Sari

Uppada Sari is a sari style woven in Uppada of East Godavari district of Andhra Pradesh. The name Jamdani in the Uppada Jamdani Sari is a Persian terminology, in which Jam means flower and Dani means Vase. Weavers uses pure lace (silver zari often dipped in melted gold) and also finest silk of Bengaluru area. Uppada Jamdani saris are known for their light weight though it gets design on both sides.

[img[http://image6.buzzintown.com/files/event/upload_72000/upload_detailcrop/365976-uppada-special-designer-exhibition.jpg]]

[img[http://image6.buzzintown.com/files/event/upload_72000/upload_detailcrop/365974-uppada-special-designer-exhibition.JPG]]

!!!Venkatagiri Sarees

Venkatagiri Sari is a sari style woven in Venkatagiri of Nellore district in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. The history of the sari dates back to the early 1700's during the rule of Venkatagiri. In those days, they were mostly weaved for queens, royal women and Zamindaris. The saris are made from fine cotton and the most significant is the use of zari. The handlooms in Venkatagiri are famous for its softness and durability.

[img[http://www.thehindu.com/multimedia/dynamic/01282/NLGRKHI-W098_GN_HY_1282448e.jpg]]

!!!Mangalagiri Sarees and Fabrics
Mangalagiri Sarees and Fabrics are produced by performing handicraft weaving in Mangalagiri, a town in Guntur district of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. Mangalagiri saris are unique variety, woven from  cotton and has the most characteristic features such like zari on the border and no woven designs on the body. The uniqueness of Mangalgiri cotton is due to its durability. The fabric is woven only on pit loom, and there are no gaps on the weave towards the edges of the fabric
The Mangalgiri saree has no embellishments on its main body. It has a zari or golden thread work embellished Nizam border and pallu. These geometrical and simple designs are inspired by the tribal designs.

[img[http://www.teluguone.com/toneshop/images/bigimages/0513-mangalagiri-Nizam-Border-sarees-mrr-00011.jpg]]

!!!Dharmavaram Handloom Pattu Sarees and Paavadas
Dharmavaram Handloom Pattu Sarees and Paavadas are textiles woven by hand with mulberry silk and zari. They are made in Dharmavaram of Kurnool district in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh. The saris are worn in winter or cold conditions, for functions, and are mostly used by dancers of Bharath Natyam and Kuchipudi.

[img[http://cdn.shopclues.com/images/detailed/2225/DSCN5198_1387776629.jpg]]


!!!Bobbile Veena

Bobbili Veena is a large plucked string instrument used in Carnatic classical music. Bobbili Veena is considered to be invented in Bobbili of Vizianagaram district, Andhra Pradesh. Bobbili Veenas are mostly Ekanda Veenas, which means they are carved out of one single piece of jackfruit wood. Other veenas have more than two joints. The sound of the Ekanda Veena is more melodious than veenas having more joints. Also the Bobbili Veena has seven frets (strings) and we use brass for two frets and steel for the other five frets. Others use different metals, including bell metal and brass, but the frets are the same in number.

[img[http://www.zazspot.com/products/19320326veena.jpg]]

!!!Tirupathi Laddu

Tirupati Laddu or is the Laddu sweet offered as Naivedhyam to Lord Sri Venkateswara, at Tirumala Venkateswara Temple of Tirupati in Chittoor District of Andhra Pradesh, India.
Its uniqueness is disputed. But  the GI status helped curb the rampant fake laddu business in Tirupati.

[img[http://media.indiatimes.in/media/content/2015/Aug/tirumala_1438866589.jpg]]

!!!Guntur Sannam Chilli

Guntur Sannam or Capsicum annuum var. Longhum, is one of the most famous types of chillies and has a huge demand throughout the world.[1][2] It widely grows in Guntur district of Andhra Pradesh and Warangal, Khammam districts of Telangana in India.
Guntur Sannam chilli has specific characteristics that have enabled it to earn international and national acclaim. Sannam chilli is generally known to trade as a S4 type chilli and is mainly used for its pungency and for the extraction and derivation of capsaicin.

[img[http://ukchilliseeds.co.uk/ekmps/shops/chilliwizard/images/teja-indian-rare-chilli-pepper-seeds-x-10-433-p.jpg]]







!!Handicrafts
!!!Kotpad Handloom fabric
Kotpad Handloom is a vegetable Dyed Fabric woven by the tribal weavers of Kotpad village. The natural dye is made from the 'Aul' tree grown in this area. The main colours extracted are black and maroon.

[img[https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/236x/a7/d5/69/a7d569af590be08ba1f1ab2dc0c93d4c.jpg]]

!!!Orissa Ikat
Orissa Ikat is a kind of ikat (double ikat), a resist dyeing technique, originating from Indian state of Odisha (Eastern and Western region of Orissa or Odisha), also known as "Bandha of Orissa".It is made through a process of tie-dying the warp and weft threads to create the design on the loom prior to weaving. The type of fabric used is silk.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Sambalpuri_Saree.jpg/320px-Sambalpuri_Saree.jpg]]

!!!Konark Stone carving
Stone carving is practiced by artisans mainly in Puri, Bhubaneswar, and Cuttack district. The art form primarily consists of custom carved works, with the Sun Temple of Konark and its intricate sculpture and delicate carvings on the red vivid sandstone exemplifying the superb workmanship of the artisans.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Stone_work_at_Konark_Orissa_India.jpg/640px-Stone_work_at_Konark_Orissa_India.jpg]]

!!!Orissa Pattachitra
This old tradition (more than thousand years old) of Oriya painting still survives in the places like Puri, Raghurajpur, Paralakhemundi, Chikiti and Sonepur. Pattachitra is a general term for traditional, cloth-based scroll painting. In the Sanskrit language, "Patta" literally means "cloth" and "Chitra" means "picture". The painters use vegetable and mineral colours and paintings are made fully old traditional way by Chitrakaras that is Oriya Painter. 
Another type is the Palm leaf pattachitra which is in Oriya language known as Tala Pattachitra drawn on palm leaf.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/53/Patta_Chitra_01.jpg]]

!!!Pipli Applique Work
Applique in textiles and ceramics is the technique of superimposing embellishments, such as small pieces of fabric and round mirrors, onto a large base fabric. Pipli is a town in Odisha, where the craft of applique is held in high esteem. The craft of applique is also prominent in the states of Bihar and Rajasthan.

[img[http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_jlViOE7SUDg/RwDX751jLoI/AAAAAAAABbA/xh1A21rd2oQ/s400/pipli1.jpg]]
[img[http://strandofsilk.com/sites/default/files/journeymap/Strand%20of%20Silk%20-%20Journey%20Map%20-%20Pipli%20Applique%20-%20Introduction%20-%20chariots.jpg]]

!!!Khandua Saree and Fabrics
Khandua (Also Maniabandi or Kataki) is a traditional "bandha" or ikat sari produced from Odisha. Place of origin is Cuttak. Khandua is traditionally red or orange in color. The red color is prepared naturally from the sal tree.

!!!Gopalpur Tussar Fabrics
Gopalpur village of Jajpur District is famous for Tussar fabrics in India. Tusser and also known as (Sanskrit) Kosa Silk) is produced from larvae of several species of silk worms which live on wild forest trees of South Asia. Tussar is valued for its rich texture and natural deep gold colour.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/Tussar_Fabrics.jpg]]

!!!Dhalapathar Parda & Fabrics
The Handicraft belongs to Dhalapathara Village of Bolagarh, Khurda district and is hand-made spinning machine by using natural colour in thread.

!!!Sambalpuri Bandha Saree & Fabrics
An important feature of these sarees is the traditional craftsmanship of the 'Bandhakala', the Tie-dye art reflected in their intricate weaves, also known as Sambalpuri "Ikkat". In this technique, the threads are first tie-dyed and later woven into a fabric, with the entire process taking many weeks.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Sambalpuri_sari_DSC_0496.JPG/320px-Sambalpuri_sari_DSC_0496.JPG]]

!!!Bomkai Saree & Fabrics
Bomkai Sari (also Sonepuri Sari) is a handloom saree from Odisha, India. It is an origin of Bomkai, Ganjam district in the state.
The saree is extra-ordinarily woven in the end piece (pallu) with several contrasting colours and designs. The weaving of Bomkai saree is time consuming and labour intensive.

[img[http://www.orissahandloom.com/image-addi.php?pic=1001128&size=560]]

!!!Habaspuri Saree & Fabrics
Habaspuri is a cotton-based traditional handloom textiles. Habaspuri handloom is named after the village of Habaspur where it was originally woven during 19 CE.

[img[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/HABASPURI_Kalahandi_Sari.jpg/159px-HABASPURI_Kalahandi_Sari.jpg]]

!!!Berhampur Patta (Phoda Kumbha) Saree & Joda
The Berhampuri silk saree is unique due to its typical Odissi style of weaving and kumbha, particularly phoda, temple type design. The weaving technique is said to have originated over 200 years ago. The finely woven sarees were known to be exported to Southeast Asian and other countries.

[img[http://creativeodisha.com/Upload/ArticleGalleryImage/e6538509-042e-48a2-825f-1fc3126600df.jpg]]

!!Agricultural
''Ganjam Kewda Rooh''

Ganjam Kewda Rooh (Screw pine) is a plant native to the Indian state of Odisha primarily in the Ganjam district. They are found between the rivers Rushikulya on the north and Bahuda on the south (45 km x 15 km coastal belt). It is an economically important species due to its male inflorescence which are used for the fragrant tender white spathes covering the flowers. The perfumery products including Kewda attar, Kewda water and Kewda oil.

[img[http://www.punmiris.com/himg/o.19065.jpg]]

''Ganjam Kewda Flower''

Kewra is an extract from the male flowers of a screw-pine tree.

!!Textile
''Orissa Pattachitra (Logo)''

The over 1400-year old “Patachitra” painting of Odisha received a major stimulus with the launch of a Geographical Indication Logo to brand the unique art form of Odisha across the globe.

[img[http://indiaeducationdiary.in/image11/Odisha_Patachitra_GI_logo.jpg]]







*Leading state in GIs- 26 pending, will take total number to 50
*Handicraft
**Salem Fabric-Unlike the organised textile mills engaged in production of cotton sarees and shirtings, the yarn-dyed fabric produced by the Salem weavers are turned out straight, thus eliminating certain pre-fabric processes such as desizing, dyeing or printing
**Kancheepuram Silk-Popularly known as Kanjivaram Sarees, the sarees are referred to as South India's answer to Banarasi saris; Kancheepuram Region.	
**Bhavani Jamakkalam-Bedheets, Erode District
**Madurai Sungudi-The traditional Sungudi sari is hand-woven, has single dot patterns and dyed with natural dyes; Artisans and weavers are from Sourashtra community who migrated to Madurai few centuries ago.
**Thanjavur Paintings-South India Classical Painting;The art form draws its immediate resources and inspiration from way back about 1600 AD, a period when the Nayakas of Thanjavur under the suzerainty of the Vijayanagara.	
**Temple Jewellery of Nagercoil-The craft technique is passed from father to son; Started when rajahs of Chettinad got their jewelery made from local artisans and donated it to the temple; Jewelery sets for Bharatnatyam are very famous
**Thanjavur Art Plate-It is a handicraft consisting of metals such as silver, bronze, and copper embossed with figures of gods and goddesses at its center, exclusively made in Thanjavur.
**Salem silk- Salem Silk known as Salem Venpattu refer to silk clothes made in Salem, Tamil Nadu
**Kovai Cora Cotton-Kovai Kora cotton is made from a blend of silk and cotton.A superior quality cotton yarn is mixed with traditional silk to produce kora cotton.The sarees have bright colored border designs with occasional use of shining zari.	
**Arani Silk-Arani Sari is a traditional sari made in Arani, Tamil Nadu. The silk is very shiny and shimmery
**Swamimalai Bronze Icons-During the reign of Chola empire, Raja Raja I commissioned a group of sculptors for the construction of the Brihadeeswarar Temple at Thanjavur.The sculptors helped sculpt statues for Airavatesvara Temple and later settled at Swamimalai.
**Thanjavur Doll-Thanjavur doll is a type of traditional Indian bobblehead or roly-poly toy made of terracotta material. The centre of gravity and total weight of the doll is concentrated at its bottom-most central core all the time so as to present a dance-like continuous movement with slow-damping oscillations.
**Pattamadai Pai (‘Pattamadai Mat’)-silky mats crafted out of korai grass (Reed plant) also called as Indian Chattai; done by Labbai Muslim weavers with korai grass grown on the banks of river Tamiraparani in Pattamadai village	
**Nachiarkoil Kuthuvilakku (‘Nachiarkoil Lamp’)-known as Nachiarkoil Kuthuvilakku;The lamps are suspended from the ceiling and richly decorated and always excellent in workmanship and design.
**Chettinad Kottan-which is the traditional palm leaf basket. Very colourful	
**Toda Embroidery(recently added)-also locally known as "pukhoor"is an art work among the Toda pastoral people of Nilgiris; made exclusively by their women;appears like a woven cloth but is made with use of red and black threads with a white cotton cloth background; greek influence
**Thanjavur Veenai-Made from jackfruit wood.
*Manufactured	
**E. I. Leather- East India Leather is an Indian vegetable-tanned leather produced by the tanneries in Tiruchi and Dindigul in Tamil Nadu.
**Coimbatore Wet Grinder- wet grinder made from granite, which is easily avaialable in coimbatore
*Agriculture	
**Eathomozhy Tall Coconut-	
**Nilgiri (Orthodox) Logo(for nilgiri tea)	
**Virupakshi Hill Banana-Hill bananas are perennial in nature; longer shelf life and  have a special favour; very sensitive to Banana bunchy top virus (BBTV). 	
**Sirumalai Hill Banana- same as above.
**Madurai Malli-A type of jasmine; The colour and the fragrance of the flower stay intact for two days due to its thick petal because of delayed anthesis,Around noon it turns milky white and then creamy white with a tint of silver shine by evening






[img[https://s23.postimg.org/ct5gthmqj/GNB.jpg]]

*Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria are differentiated chiefly by their cell wall structure.
*One of the several unique characteristics of Gram-negative bacteria is the structure of the bacterial outer membrane. The outer leaflet of this membrane comprises a complex lipopolysaccharide (LPS) whose lipid portion acts as an endotoxin.
*If gram-negative bacteria enter the circulatory system, the liposaccharide can cause a toxic reaction. This results in fever, an increased respiratory rate, and low blood pressure. This may lead to life-threatening condition of endotoxic shock.
*The outer membrane protects the bacteria from several antibiotics, dyes, and detergents that would normally damage either the inner membrane or the cell wall (made of peptidoglycan). The outer membrane provides these bacteria with resistance to lysozyme and penicillin. However, alternative medicinal treatments have been developed to combat the protective outer membrane of some pathogenic gram-negative organisms.






The Grand Trunk Road is one of Asia's oldest and longest major roads. It runs from Chittagong, Bangladesh to Kabul in Afghanistan.

[img[http://s17.postimg.org/oqost1067/map.jpg]]

Howrah, Dhanbad, Varanasi, Allahabad, Kanpur, Ghaziabad, Delhi, Ludhiana, and Amritsar (Wagha border), are some of the major cities the G.T. Road passes through.

''Relation with Silk Road:''

It was more ancient than the Silk Road and was integrated to it as shown in the pic below during the time of Kushans (30 – 375 AD) who helped spread Buddhism into China via Silk Road.

[img[http://s27.postimg.org/peqxv932r/Transasia_trade_routes_1st_C_CE_gr2.png]]

''Mauryan Times (322-185 BCE):''

*A part of the current route spanning the Grand Trunk Road was in existence known as Uttarapatha (Road to the North). 
*Constructed in eight stages, this road is said to have connected the cities of Purushapura/Gandhara (Peshawar), Takshashila (Taxila), Hastinapura (Hastinapur), Kanyakubja (Kannauj), Prayag (Allahabad), Pataliputra (Patna) and Tamralipta (Tamluk) at the mouth of the Ganges in Bengal from Balkh in modern-day Afghanistan and officials were appointed by Chandragupta Maurya exclusively to oversee the maintenance of the road according to Megasthenes, a Greek diplomat.
''Sher Shah Suri:''

Sher Shah Suri was the original architect of what is now known as the complete stretch of the G.T. Road. His objective was to facilitate trade during his reign and connect his hometown, Sasaram in Bihar, to Agra, his capital. The road was renamed Sadak-e-Azam (Great Road).

''Mughal Era:''

The Mughals extended the eastern point of the road to Chittagong (in Bangladesh). They extended the western point to Kabul.

''British Times:''

Lord William Bentinck initiated the improvement of the road (1833 and 1860), which was later renamed as ‘Grand Trunk Road’. The British connected Howrah and Peshawar to the stretch.

[img[http://s27.postimg.org/cjsljcjir/Route.jpg]]






*It’s a 2D carbon allotrope, Zero-gap semiconductor (because its valence and conduction bands meet at dirac point).
*Structure: polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon ( honey comb like structure means each atom in hexagonal lattice is a vertex). Each atom has four bonds: one σ bond with each of its three neighbors and one π-bond that is oriented out of plane. The atoms are about 1.42 Å apart. 
!!!Material properties
*Strength: 200 times stronger than steel.
*Thinnest material on earth -- 1 million times thinner than human hair.
!!!Interesting facts
*It is just one-atom thick but absorbs 2.3% of light so it can be seen with the naked eye. It can potentially be used to create semi-transparent electronics.
*Discovered by Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov in 2004 at the University of Manchester and won Noble prize in physics in 2010.
*Uses: in semiconductor industry, desalination, in making light weight/strong composite materials, photovoltaics.
*Recently, graphene film which can absorb 95%  of light incident on it,has been discovered.






Green building (also known as green construction or sustainable building) refers to both a structure and the using of processes that are environmentally responsible and resource-efficient throughout a building's life-cycle: from siting to design, construction, operation, maintenance, renovation, and demolition.

In other words, green building design involves finding the balance between homebuilding and the sustainable environment. The Green Building practice expands and complements the classical building design concerns of economy, utility, durability, and comfort.

Internationally used rating systems: LEED, BREEM etc. Taipei 101, the tallest and largest green building of LEED Platinum certification in the world since 2011.

In India the main governmental certification for a green building is the Green Rating for Integrated Habitat Assessment (GRIHA) rating system. This assesses buildings on 34 criteria (including renewable energy, recycling, water use, etc.) and awards points out of 100 – a building must be awarded more than 50 points in order to carry a GRIHA certification. Based on their score, buildings are awarded between 1 and 5 stars.

Construction industry is contributing approximately 10% of India’s GDP. In view of such growth, the need of the hour is to focus on green building technology for efficient management of water, energy, materials ultimately paving way for sustainable development.


Example of a green building school:

[img[http://s21.postimg.org/likb9p9hz/IMG_GB.jpg]]






<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/L8gd0_RCHtM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

*IMD has given following criteria for heat waves
**A heat wave is qualified when air temperatures of at least 40°C (104 °F) in the plains or greater than 30 °C (86 °F) in the hilly regions.
**Temperatures greater than 46°C (114.8°F) are considered and classified as severe heat waves.
| !Normal maximum temperature of a station | !Heat Wave Departure from normal | !Severe Heat Wave Departure from normal |
| __<__ 40°C | 5°C to 6°C | __>__ 7°C |
| __>__ 40°C | 4°C to 5°C | __>__ 6°C |
!!!Health impacts
*The health impacts of Heat Waves typically involve dehydration, heat cramps, heat exhaustion and/or heat stroke. The signs and symptoms are as follows:
**Heat Cramps -- Edema (swelling) and Syncope (Fainting) generally accompanied by fever below 39*C i.e.102*F.
**Heat Exhaustion -- Fatigue, weakness, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps and sweating.
**Heat Stoke -- Body temperatures of 40°C i.e. 104°F or more along with delirium, seizures or coma. This is a potential fatal condition.






*The Higgs boson (or Higgs particle) is a particle that gives mass to other particles. In the 1960s Peter Higgs was the first person to think of it, and the particle was found in March 2013 at the Large Hadron Collider in CERN. It is part of the Standard Model in physics, which means it is found everywhere. It is one of the 17 particles in the Standard Model.
*The Higgs particle is a boson. Bosons are particles responsible for all physical forces except gravity. Other bosons are the photon, the W and Z bosons, and the gluon.
*It is very difficult to detect the Higgs boson with the equipment and technology we have now. These particles are believed to exist for less than a septillionth of a second. Because the Higgs boson has so much mass (compared to other particles), it takes a lot of energy to create one. The Large Hadron Collider at CERN is the equipment scientists used to find it. The collider has enough energy that it is able to make Higgs bosons.






<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0TipTogQT3E" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>






*Humans of New York (HONY) is a blog and bestselling book featuring street portraits and interviews collected on the streets of New York City.
*Started in November 2010 by photographer Brandon Stanton, Humans of New York has developed a large following through social media.
*Inspired by Humans of New York, hundreds of ‘Humans of’ blogs have developed around the world including in India.

[img[http://s31.postimg.org/bgwjnlmxn/India_s_overseas_oil_and_gas_blocks.jpg]]






The Oil Industrial Development Board (OIDB) created the Indian Strategic Petroleum Reserves Ltd (ISPRL) to serve as the controlling government agency for the strategic reserve.

The facilities are located at:

*Padur, Karnataka - 2.5 million tonnes storage
*Mangalore, Karnataka - 1.5 million tonnes storage
*Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh - 1.33 million tonnes storage


Their combined capacity is 5.33 million tonne, enough to meet nation's oil requirement of about 10 days. Their purpose is to guard against global price shocks ans supply disruptions.

UAE's Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) has agreed to store crude oil in India's maiden strategic storage and gave two third of the oil for free. Adnoc uses half of the 1.5 million tonne Manglore facility. It will stock 0.75 million tonne of which 0.5 million tonne will belong to India and can be used in emergency. Adnoc will use the facility as a warehouse for trading its oil.






*Indian Council of Historical Research is an autonomous organization established under Societies Registration Act 1860, in 1972
*Objectives
**to provide a forum for historians to come together and exchange views
**objective and scientific writing of history and rational presentation and interpretation.
**to promote research in history and emphasise on areas that receieve inadequate attention
** to disseminate the results of such researches.
*Functions
**provides fellowhips and financial assitance to scholars, teachers and registered rearch organizations
**holds symposia seminars and workshops
**provides publication subsidy to seminars and journals
**publishes journals in english and hindi
**maintains large library and documentation centre
*ICHR council consists
**chairman of council is nominated by GOI who shall be an eminant historian-
**18 other historians nominated by GOI
**Representative of UGC
**DG of ASI
**DG of National Archives of India
**4 persons to represent GOI each from Ministry of education ,department of culture, ministry of finance and the member secretary appointed by ICHR od deputation from MHrD






*Insider trading is the trading of a public company's stock or other securities (such as bonds or stock options) by individuals with access to nonpublic information about the company.
*In various countries, trading based on insider information is illegal -- this is because it is seen as unfair to other investors who do not have access to the information as the investor with insider information could potentially make far larger profits that a typical investor could not make.






*Institutions under ''The Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960''
**Animal Welfare Board of India -- works under MoEFCC, recognises animal welfare organisation, finances these, suggests changes to animal laws and rules, publications to raise awareness
**Committee for the Purpose of Supervision and Control of Experiments on Animals -- under MoEFCC, register establishments that conduct tests on animals, approval of animal house facilites, actions against establishments in case of violation
**National Institute of Animal Welfare -- under MoEFCC, provides training and education related to animal welfare management
**Wildlife Institute of India -- Dehradun, under MoEFCC carries out research in biodiveristy endangered species wildlife policy etc.
**Laboratory for the conservation of Endanngered species -- Hyderabad under CSIR, one of its kind facility in India, research in conservation and preservation of wildlife and its resources.
**NGOs -- PETA, Wildlife SOS, Wildlife Rescue and Rehablitation Centre (charitable Trust)






The International Court of Justice (ICJ) is the main court of the United Nations, established by the U. N. Charter, in 1945. It is located at The Hague, in the Netherlands.
There are 15 judges sitting on the Court. The court has two main functions:

*settling legal disputes between member States (there are 192 of these) submitted to it by them and 
*giving advisory opinions on legal matters referred to it by agencies of the United Nations. 

The International Court of Justice has no jurisdiction to try individuals accused of war crimes or crimes against humanity.

The International Criminal Court's function is to try individuals accused of war crimes or crimes against humanity.







*NASA (USA), RFSA (Russia), ESA (EU), CSA (Canada), JAXA (Japan)
*The ISS maintains an orbit with an altitude of between 330 and 435 km (205 and 270 mi) by means of reboost manoeuvres using the engines of the Zvezda module or visiting spacecraft.
*Expedition 47 is the current and 47th expedition to the International Space Station

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bJ3oTTm_Pdo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QSIPNhOiMoE" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

*With IoT the physical world becomes one big information system;
*Computing concept where everyday physical objects will be connected to Internet and be able to identify themselves to other devices. So that many objects will act in unison called as “ ambient intelligence” eg smartwatches that track weares’ heartbeat and send info to smartphone through bluetooth
*IoT can be broken down in 3 layers --
**Rudimentary like camera monitoring
**Things that are controlled without any integrated system like drones, sensors in plant assemblies
**Integrated systems like internet controlled plants or actuators in complex plants.






*ICPO-INTERPOL -- is a network of police forces from 190 countries all over the world. It is not a supranational agency, it act as liasion-in body in cases of cross border crimes, disasters, terrorist attacks, etc.
*Its headquarters, secretariat are located at Lyon,France.
*It has representative at UN headquarters in New York and in EU at Brussels. In addition there 7 sub-regional bureaus in Argentina, Ivory coast, El Salvador, Kenya, Thailand, Zimbabwe and Cameroon.
!!!Organisation
*The General Assembly is composed of delegates appointed by the governments of member countries. As INTERPOL's supreme governing body, it meets once a year and takes all the major decisions affecting general policy, the resources needed for international cooperation, working methods, finances and programmes of activities.
*Executive Committee -- elected by the General Assembly, the EC has 13 members, 1 president elected for 4 years; 3 vice-presidents elected for 3 years and 9 delegates from diferent countries. They are not eligible for re-election to same post or as delegates to EC.
*General Secretariat -- Headquarters in Lyon, France -- liasons with UN New York, and EU office in Brussels. It has  other regional offices -- Argentina (Buenos Aires), Cameroon (Yaoundé), Côte d’Ivoire (Abidjan), El Salvador (San Salvador), Kenya (Nairobi), Thailand (Bangkok) and Zimbabwe (Harare).
*Every member country has their own INTERPOL office, called a National Central Bureau (CBI is NCB of India), which connects that country's police force with the other members.
*I-24/7 -- is INTERPOL's secure network that links the member countries to each other and lets them search INTERPOL's international criminal databases.
*Incident Response Teams -- In the event of an international disaster, terrorist attack, or assassination, Interpol can send an Incident Response Team (IRT). IRTs can offer a range of expertise and database access to assist with victim identification, suspect identification, and the dissemination of information to other nations' law enforcement agencies.
*Interpol travel documents -- an Interpol Travel Document is a travel document issued to Interpol officers for travel to Interpol member countries. They are intended to reduce response times for personnel deployed to assist with transnational criminal investigations, major events or emergency situations by waiving normal visa requirements.
*Interpol terrorism watch list -- The Interpol Watch List is a centralized list of those persons who are subject to Interpol notices issued for arrest (red), location (blue) and information (green). Additionally, the Terrorism Watch List includes passports reported stolen.
----
<<<
;Vision
:Connecting police for a safer world
;Mision
:Preventing and fighting the crime through enhanced cooperation and innovation on police and security matters.
<<<
----
!!!History
*This word was first chosen in 1946 as telegraphic address.
*In 1956, it was called ICPC-International Criminal Police Commission.
| !Notices issued by the INTERPOL (PIBGYOR) |<|
| Red Notice | To seek the location and arrest of wanted persons with a view to extradition or similar lawful action. In the case of this notice, the persons concerned are wanted by national jurisdictions for prosecution or to serve a sentence based on an arrest warrant or court decision. |
| Yellow Notice | To help locate missing persons, often minors, or to help identify persons who are unable to identify themselves. |
| Blue Notice | To collect additional information about a person’s identity, location or activities in relation to a crime. |
| Black Notice | To seek information on unidentified bodies. |
| Green Notice | To provide warnings and intelligence about persons who have committed criminal offences and are likely to repeat these crimes in other countries. |
| Orange Notice | To warn of an event, a person, an object or a process representing a serious and imminent threat to public safety. |
| Purple Notice | To seek or provide information on modus operandi, objects, devices and concealment methods used by criminals. |
| INTERPOL–United Nations Security Council Special Notice | Issued for groups and individuals who are the targets of [[UN Security Council Sanctions Committees|UNSC Committees dealing with Counter Terrorism]]. |






*The Internet Protocol (IP) specifies the technical format of packets and the addressing scheme for computers to communicate over a network.
*IPv4 is the fourth revision of the IP used to identify devices on a network through an addressing system. IPv4 is the most widely deployed Internet protocol used to connect devices to the Internet. 
*IPv4 uses a 32-bit address scheme allowing for a total of 2^^32^^ addresses (just over 4 billion addresses) and is written in decimal as four numbers separated by periods. Each number can be zero to 255. For example, 1.160.10.240 could be an IP address.  
*With the growth of the Internet it is expected that the number of unused IPv4 addresses will eventually run out because every device including computers, smartphones and game consoles that connects to the Internet requires an address.
*IPv6 is also called IPng (Internet Protocol next generation) and it is the newest version of the Internet Protocol (IP) reviewed in the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standards committees to replace the current version of IPv4.
*It was designed as an evolutionary upgrade to the Internet Protocol and will, in fact, coexist with the older IPv4 for some time. IPv6 is often referred to as the //next generation// Internet standard and has been under development now since the mid-1990s. 
*IPv6 addresses are 128-bit IP address written in hexadecimal and separated by colons. An example IPv6 address could be written like this: 3ffe:1900:4545:3:200:f8ff:fe21:67cf. IPv6 was born out of concern that the demand for IP addresses would exceed the available supply.
*While increasing the pool of addresses is one of the most often-talked about benefit of IPv6, there are other important technological changes in IPv6 that will improve the IP protocol --
**No more NAT (Network Address Translation)
**Auto-configuration
**No more private address collisions
**Better multicast routing
**Simpler header format
**Simplified, more efficient routing
**True quality of service (QoS), also called "flow labeling"
**Built-in authentication and privacy support
**Flexible options and extensions
**Easier administration






*The development of the Orbital Vehicle began in 2006.
*It was designed to carry two astronauts and to land in water upon re-entry. ISRO had launched and recovered the 550-kg Space Recovery Capsule in January 2007.
*ISRO undertook a successful test launch of the vehicle aboard the GSLV Mk3 X1 launched from SDSC, Sriharikota on December 2014.






*Modeled on its British counterpart, the JIC is responsible for directing the national intelligence organizations and analyzing intelligence data.
*The JIC operates with its own Secretariat that works under the [[Cabinet Secretariat]].

*The Keystone XL pipeline is a proposed 1,179-mile (1,897km) pipe that would run from the [[oil sands|Oil sands]] in Alberta, Canada to Steele City, Nebraska (crossing the US -- Canada border), where it could join an existing pipe.






*Khadi or Khaddar- handspun/handwoven cloth from bangladesh, India, Pakistan on a spinning wheel //charkha//
*Primarily made in cotton, but also in silk and wool
*Versatile; cool in summer, warm in winter.
*Khadi was made an integral part of Swadeshi movement of 1920s by Gandhi
*Gandhi wrote about Adoption of Khadi and self sufficiency of villages in magazine __Young India__
*Local variations --
**Muslin -- Comilla, Chandina, Muradnagar of Bangladesh-Huen Tsang of China 6th century and Marco Polo in 12th century have described about Muslin
**Khaddar -- Kamalia in Pakistan

*[[Khadi and Village Industries Commission]]

*Statutory Body, formed under ''Khadi and Village Industries Commission Act, 1956''
*Under Ministry of Small and Medium Enterprises
*Objectives of KVIC
**Providing employment in rural areas
**Providing Salable articles
**Building strong rural ccommunity spirit and making them self-reliant






*Kudumbashree is a female-oriented, community-based, poverty reduction project of the Government of Kerala launched in 1998.
*The mission aims at the empowerment of women, through forming self-help groups and encouraging their entrepreneurial or other wide range of activities. The purpose of the mission is to ensure that the women should no longer remain as passive recipients of public assistance, but active leaders in women-involved development initiatives.
*In 2012, Kudumbashree was recognized as a [[National Resource Organisation]] (NRO) by [[Ministry of Rural Development]] (MoRD), Government of India, under the [[National Rural Livelihood Mission]] (NRLM).
*Subsequently, Kudumbashree NRO signed Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) with 8 States to provide technical and implementation support to their State Rural Livelihood Missions (SRLMs) for the replication of Kudumbahsree’s best practices.






!!!Background
*Several scientists of the Indian Origin were also involved in the discovery of Gravitational waves that confirmed a major prediction of Albert Einstein’s 1915 general theory of relativity.
*Physicists have concluded that the detected gravitational waves were produced during the final fraction of a second of the merger of two black holes to produce a single, more massive spinning black hole. This collision of two black holes had been predicted but never observed.
*The twin LIGO detectors are located in Livingston, Louisiana, and Hanford, Washington. The LIGO observatories are funded by the US National Science Foundation (NSF), and were conceived, built and are operated by Caltech and MIT.

!!!Indian Government clears proposal for Gravitational Wave Detector
*The Union cabinet approved a proposal to establish a state-of-the-art gravitational wave observatory in India in collaboration with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) in the US. This is known as ‘LIGO-India project’.
 *The “in principle” approval for the ‘LIGO-India project’ for research on gravitational waves is piloted by the Department of Atomic Energy and Department of Science and Technology (DST).
''Key Details''

*The LIGO-India project will be jointly coordinated and executed by three Indian research institutions. It is piloted by Department of Atomic Energy (DAE) and Department of Science and Technology (DST). 
**Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics (IUCAA), Pune
**Department of Atomic Energy organisations: Institute for Plasma Research (IPR), Gandhinagar
**Raja Ramanna Centre for Advanced Technology (RRCAT), Indore.
''Significance of this project''

*Dubbed as the breakthrough of the century, the international team of scientists believes that the detection of gravitational waves will open an unprecedented new window to the cosmos.
*Gravitational waves carry information about their dramatic origins and about the nature of gravity that cannot be obtained from elsewhere.
*The project will bring unprecedented opportunities for scientists and engineers to dig deeper into the realm of gravitational wave and take global leadership in this new astronomical frontier.
*The LIGO-India project will also bring considerable opportunities in cutting-edge technology for the Indian industry which will be engaged in the construction of the eight-km long beam tube at ultra-high vacuum on a levelled terrain.
*With its establishment, India will join the global network of gravitational wave detectors.
*Establishing an observatory in India also assumes importance because the further the distance between the observatories, the greater will be the accuracy in locating gravity waves.






*Law Commission of India is an executive body established by an order of the Government of India.
*Its major function is to work for legal reform. Its membership primarily comprises legal experts, who are entrusted a mandate by the Government.
*The Commission is established for a fixed tenure and works as an advisory body to the Ministry of Law and Justice.
*The first Law Commission was established during the British regime in 1834 by the Charter Act of 1833. After that three more Commissions were established in pre-independent India.
*The first Law Commission of independent India was established in 1955 for a three-year term.
*Justice Balbir Singh Chauhan, a former judge of the Supreme Court was appointed Chairman of the 21st Law Commission on 10 March -- one of the key issues pending before the Law Commission is a call on amending the Indian Penal Code (IPC) amid allegations of abuse and arbitrary use of the law.

*Madame Tussauds is a wax museum in London with branches in a number of major cities -- founded by wax sculptor Marie Tussaud.
*It has expanded and will expand with branches in Shanghai, Singapore, Sydney, Vienna, Washington, D.C., etc.
*In November 2015, Madame Tussauds announced that it would open a museum in New Delhi in 2017.
*Prime Minister Narendra Modi will soon join the ranks of prominent global leaders at Madame Tussauds in London, Singapore, Hong Kong and Bangkok.






*madhu.madhavi1101@gmail.com






----
<<<
*This is a rural wage employment programme in India.
*It provides for a legal guarantee of at least 100 days of unskilled wage employment in a financial year to rural households whose adult members are willing to engage in unskilled manual work at a pre-determined minimum wage rate.
*Budget provision hovered around 40,000-50,000 crores under this programme.
*The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) completes ten years of implementation on 2nd February 2016.
<<<
----
!!!Objectives
*To enhance the livelihood security of the rural poor by generating wage employment opportunities
*To create a rural asset base which would enhance productive ways of employment, augment and sustain rural household income.
!!!Background
*MGNREGA was initially implemented as National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (NREGA) in 200 selected backward districts in India on February 2, 2006.
*It was extended to an additional 130 districts with effect from April 1, 2007.
*Later, the remaining 285 districts were covered from April 1, 2008.
*The National Rural Employment Guarantee (Amendment) Act, 2009 renamed NREGA as MGNREGA.
!!!Salient features
*Section 4(1) of MGNREGA mandates the design and implementation of State-specific Rural Employment Guarantee Schemes (REGS) to give effect to the provisions made in MGNREGA.
*Section 6(1) empowers the Central Government to specify the wage rates for MGNREGA beneficiaries. So far, the wage rates have been modified three times, the latest being on January 14, 2011 where the base minimum wage rate of Rs. 100 was indexed to inflation.
*MGNREGA is unique in not only ensuring at least 100 days of employment to the willing unskilled workers, but also in ensuring an enforceable commitment on the implementing machinery i.e., the State Governments, and providing a bargaining power to the labourers. The failure of provision for employment within 15 days of the receipt of job application from a prospective household will result in the payment of unemployment allowance to the job seekers.
!!!Implementation
*The implementation of MGNREGA largely depends on the active participation of three-tier decentralized self governance units called Panchayat institutions.
*The panchayats are required to estimate labour demand, identify works and demarcate work sites, prioritize works, prepare village/block/district level development plans in advance for the continuous and smooth planning and the execution of this wage employment programme
* The Panchayats are responsible for processing the registration of job seekers, issuance of job cards, receipts of applications for employment, allotment of jobs, identification of work sites, planning, allocation and execution of works, payment of wages and commencement of social audit, transparency and accountability check at the grass-root level.
----
<<<
*The implementation of MGNREGA has influenced the wage structure in rural areas as the minimum wages for agricultural labourers across States have witnessed an upward trend between 2006 and 2010.
*The Act has broadened the occupational choices available to the agricultural workers within their locality, thereby impacting rural-urban migration.
<<<
----
!!!Achievements
*Since the start of the programme, the expenditure on the programme has amounted to Rs. 3,13,844.55 crore and out of this 71% has been spent on wage payments to workers.
*Of the workers, the percentage of Scheduled Caste workers has consistently been about 20% and Scheduled Tribe workers has been about 17%.
*A total of 1,980.01 crore persondays have been generated, out of which the percentage worked by women has steadily increased much above the statutory minimum of 33%.
*Sustainable assets have been created linked to conservation of natural resources and overall development of Gram Panchayats.
*More than 65% of the works taken up under the programme are linked to agriculture and allied activities.
!!!Other Data
*The percentage of rural households completing 100 days of work ranges from a low of 2% in Uttar Pradesh—one of the worst-hit states—to 3.7% in Chhattisgarh, 4.5% in Madhya Pradesh, 4.6% in Odisha, and 5.5% in Karnataka. Some of the better performing states are Telangana (7.3%), Andhra Pradesh (8%), Jharkhand (8.2%) and Maharashtra (12.2%). The national average is a dismal 4.8%.
!!!Recent developments 
*An electronic fund management system has been successfully instituted which allows for real time and transparent release of funds to implementing agencies and beneficiaries. There has been consistent coordination between banks and post offices and constant monitoring of pendency of payments has led to a reduction in wage delays.
*The Ministry has reacted swiftly to the distress situation of droughts in nine states by declaring an additional 50 days of employment in the drought affected areas.
