*There are three types of committees --
**Ad hoc -- created on a temporary basis to deal with certain matters. They dissolve after their purpose.
**Standing -- part of the permanent machinery of government for which appropriate secretariat organisation may be provided on a permanent basis.
**Subcommittee
!!!Standing Committees of the Cabinet:
*Appointments Committee of the Cabinet (ACC) -- decides all higher level appointments in the Cabinet Secretariat, Public enterprises, Banks and Financial Institutions.
*Cabinet Committee on Accommodation(CCA)
*Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA) -- directs and coordinates the governmental activities in the economic sphere.
*Cabinet Committee on Parliamentary Affairs (CCPaA)-- looks after the progress of government business in the Parliament.
*Cabinet Committee on Political Affairs (CCPA) -- deals with all policy matters pertaining to domestic and foreign affairs.
*Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS) -- decides on India's defence expenditure, matters of National Security, and makes significant appointments.
----
*Three of the Cabinet Committees, the ACC, CCA and the Cabinet Committee on Parliamentary Affairs deal with internal housekeeping and functioning of the Government.
*CCA and CCPaA headed by Home Minister -- rest all headed by PM.
----
!!!Role of Cabinet Committees:
*The cabinet committees wield real power of decision on less important general policy matters. Only the delicate and complex points, or those on which ministers differ, remain for discussion by the cabinet.
*A cabinet decision and a parliamentary enactment including the budget has to pass through several committee screenings to reach to adequacy or acceptability.
*The committee system safeguards the principle of collective responsibility, which is an essential feature of the cabinet system.
*Cabinet committees increase the effectiveness of political control over public services (The public servants are called upon by the committees to justify their proposals and comment on problems under review.)
*The committees also act as a collective check on individual ministers and on the Prime Minister too (since it eliminates the possibility of any one department carrying a disproportionate weight of opinion.)






*Background of Indian Penal Code, Criminal Procedure Code, The Criminal Law Act 1952, Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
*Public employees -- of public undertakings, cooperative societies that receive govt aid, UGC, vice-chancellors, professors, scientists ''not MLAs and MPs''.
*Controversial sections -- Section 13 -- definition of criminal misconduct and penal provisons like jail upto 7 years -- this was used against Manmohan Singh, Kumar Manglam Birla and PC Parakh in Coalgate Scam






*Prevention of Money Laundering Act, 2002 is an Act of the Parliament of India enacted to prevent money-laundering and to provide for confiscation of property derived from money-laundering.
!!!Salient features
*The Act and Rules notified there under impose obligation on banking companies, financial institutions and intermediaries to verify identity of clients, maintain records and furnish information in prescribed form to Financial Intelligence Unit - India (FIU-IND) 
*Any person found guilty of money-laundering shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment from three years to seven years and if the crimes are related to Offences under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substance Act, 1985, the maximum punishment may extend to 10 years instead of 7 years. 
*Appropriate authorities, appointed by the Govt of India, can provisionally attach property believed to be "proceeds of crime" for 180days. Such an order is required to be confirmed by an independent Adjudicating Authority
*The Adjudicating Authority (appointed by central govt through notification) shall not be bound by the procedure laid down by the Code of Civil Procedure,1908, but shall be guided by the principles of natural justice and, subject to the other provisions of PMLA. The Adjudicating Authority shall have powers to regulate its own procedure.
*A person, who is accused of having committed the offence of money laundering, has to prove that alleged proceeds of crime are in fact lawful property. In other words, the burden of proof lies on the accused. 
*An Appellate Tribunal is the body appointed by Govt of India. It is given the power to hear appeals against the orders of the Adjudicating Authority and any other authority under the Act. Orders of the tribunal can be appealed in appropriate High Court (for that jurisdiction) and finally to the Supreme Court
*The tainted proceeds parked overseas can be recovered through mutual Legal Assistance Treaties. India has such treaties with 26 countries.
!!!Important Amendments
*The Prevention of Money Laundering Act, 2002 levies a fine up to Rs five lakh. The act was amended in 2011 like the upper ceiling of Rs 5 lakh fine was removed after india joined [[FATF|Financial Action Task Force]] in 2010.
----
<<<
*Attracts wide no, of legislations like The Indian Penal Code 1860, Offences under Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988; Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act 1985; SEBI Act 1992 etc.
*Covers illegal income as well as legal income hidden from public authorities.
*Rigorous punishment of min 3 years extendable to 10 years, liable to fine.
*Provision of attaching properties as proceeds of crime for not more than 180 days.
<<<
----






*Banks were assigned a special role in the economic development of the country, besides ensuring the growth of the financial sector. The banking regulator, the Reserve Bank of India, has hence prescribed that a portion of bank lending should be for developmental activities, which it calls the priority sector.
!!!Categories under priority sector
*Agriculture
*Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises
*Export Credit
*Education
*Housing
*Social Infrastructure -- loans up to Rs.5 crore per borrower for building schools, healthcare facilities, drinking water facilities and sanitation facilities in smaller centers.
*Renewable Energy -- loans up to Rs.15 crore to borrowers for solar, biomass, wind, micro-hydel plants and for non-conventional energy-based public utilities like street lighting systems, and remote village electrification.
*Others -- includes loans to weaker sections, PMJDY account holders, MFIs, SHGs, Persons with Disabilities, Minority communities etc.
----
<<<
''Note''

*There are specific sub-targets for each of these categories.
<<<
----
!!!Minimum limits for priority sector lending
*The limits are prescribed according to the ownership pattern of banks as can be seen below --
**According to RBI guidelines issued on 23 April, 2015 -- the overall priority sector lending target for all banks is set at 40%, while for foreign banks having under 20 branches, the target has been set at 32%.
!!!Penal action
*Scheduled Commercial Banks having any shortfall in lending to priority sector shall be allocated amounts for contribution to the [[Rural Infrastructure Development Fund]] (RIDF) established with NABARD and other Funds with NABARD/NHB/SIDBI/MUDRA Ltd., as decided by the Reserve Bank from time to time.
!!!Issues regarding Priority Sector Lending
*It has been observed that while banks often tend to meet the overall priority sector targets, they sometimes tend to miss the sub-targets.
*This is particularly true in case of domestic banks failing to meet their sub-targets for agricultural advances. One of the reasons banks often site for not lending to this sector is that recovery is often difficult.
!!!Recent Developments
*The RBI has included three new categories for lending: medium enterprises, social infrastructure and renewable energy.
*The RBI also re-introduced export credit within priority sector and said banks can buy and sell so-called [[PSL certificates|Priority Sector Lending Certificates]] after the guidelines for the same are issued later.
----
''See Also''

*[[Double Repression]]
----






*The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has released guidelines for priority sector lending certificates (PSLCs), where banks can buy and sell instruments to manage the priority sector lending limits on their loan books. Banks in need to cover for sub-targets in priority sector lending or overall targets can buy the certificate of their choice.
*The instruments are aimed at achieving the priority sector lending target and sub-targets by purchase of these instruments in the event of shortfall and at the same time incentivize banks with a surplus; thereby enhancing lending to the categories in the priority sector.
*While the issuer bank will be selling the certificates to a bank in need of achieving its targets, there will be no transfer of loan or risks, the central bank said in its guidelines.
*The nominal value of a PSLC would represent the equivalent of the priority sector lending that would get deducted from the priority sector portfolio of the seller and added to the portfolio of the buyer.
*__According to the guidelines, banks can issue four different kinds of PSLCs__ --
**Those for the shortfall in ''agriculture lending''
**Those for a shortfall in lending to ''small and marginal farmers''
**Those issued for lending to ''micro enterprises''
**Those issued for ''overall lending targets''
----
<<<
*The PSLC is a short-term accounting instrument which will expire at the end of the financial year that it has been issued in and is meant to only cover a shortfall that is largely seen in weaker public sector banks, private banks and foreign banks.
*Scheduled commercial banks (SCBs), regional rural banks (RRBs), local area banks (LABs), small finance banks (when they become operational) and urban cooperative banks are eligible to buy and sell these certificates, RBI said.
<<<
----






*The Scheme introduced by the National Savings Organization in 1968 to mobilize small savings. The Scheme offers an investment avenue with decent returns coupled with income tax benefits.
*Salient features of the Scheme are as follows --
**Eligibility -- Individuals who are residents of India are eligible to open their account under the Public Provident Fund.
**Investment limits -- a minimum of Rs.500.00 subject to a maximum of Rs.1.50 lac per annum may be deposited. The subscriber should not deposit more than Rs.1.50 lac per annum.
**Duration of scheme -- Original duration is 15 years. Thereafter, on application by the subscriber, it can be extended for 1 or more blocks of 5 years each.
**Tax benefits -- Income Tax benefits available under Sec 80C of IT Act. Interest income is totally exempt from Income Tax.
----
''See also''

*[[Pension System in India]]
----






Pyrotechnics is the science of using materials capable of undergoing self-contained and self-sustained exothermic chemical reactions for the production of heat, light, gas, smoke and/or sound.






!!!Background
*A committee consisting of stakeholders, interested ministers and industries was formed under MoS&T and coordinated by DIP(now DIPP) gave recommendations to Cabinet in 1996
*On the recommendations QCI was jointly set up by GOI with ASSOCHAM, FICCI and CII.
*Registered as Non-Profit Organisation under Socities Registartion Act, 1860.
*Nodal Minitry is Ministry of Commerce and Industry, QCI works under DIPP.
!!!Structure
*38 members and equal representation of Government, Industries and oother stakeholders
*Consist of four bodies --
**National Accredation Board for Certified Bodies -- offers accreditation to the Certification bodies and Inspection Bodies
**National Accredation Board for Education and Training -- accreditation to schools, training course providers and auditors in line with Board’s criteria; a mechanism for their international recognition
**National Accredation Board for Hospitals and Healthcare providers -- to establish and operate accreditation and allied programs for healthcare organizations
**National Board for Quality Promotion -- promote application of quality management standards and statistical quality tools; empowering the consumers to demand quality and suppliers to ensure quality
*National Accredation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories (separate Legal entity; supports QCI)
!!!Objectives
*Establish and maintain an accreditation structure.
*Provide right and unbiased information on quality related standards.
*National Quality Campaign -- to make an ecosystem of quality and related standards in the country.
*Facilitate upgradation of equipments and techniques related to quality.
*Help establish brand equity of Indian products and services.
*Swacchh Sarvekshan -- commissioned by the Ministry of Urban Development,the first for Swachh Bharat Mission; conducted by QCI in Jan 2016 in 73 major cities(40% of urban population).






https://www.youtube.com/embed/z7aqJpKfPC0






*It is the oldest multilateral international conservation convention (Ramsar, Iran in 1971) and the only one to deal with one habitat or ecosystem type, wetlands -- provides the framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and wise use of wetlands and their resources.
*Aims for conservation and sustainable utilization of wetlands, recognizing the fundamental ecological functions of wetlands and their economic, cultural, scientific, and recreational value.
*The Ramsar List of Wetlands of International Importance also known as Ramsar Sites (>2000) & out of the 169 contracting parties, the country with the highest number of sites is the United Kingdom at 170 and the country with the greatest area of listed wetlands is Bolivia.
*The Ramsar definition of wetlands is fairly wide, including //areas of marine water the depth of which at low tide does not exceed six meters// as well as fish ponds, rice paddies and salt pans.
*There are 9 criteria for identifying Wetlands of International Importance.
*International Organization Partners (IOPs) of Ramsar Convention: 
**Birdlife International
**International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)
**International Water Management Institute (IWMI)
**Wetland International
**WWF International
----
<<<
''See Also''

*[[List of wetlands in India identified as Ramsar sites]]
<<<
----






----
<<<
*Over the decades, the Supreme Court has developed a rich jurisprudence around the question of what constitutes a //reasonable restriction//.
*One of the key components of reasonableness, according to the Court, is that the restriction must be //narrowly drawn// i.e. the State must frame its laws in such a way that they restrict speech only to the extent necessary to achieve a legitimate goal. If the law goes beyond this, it is termed //over-broad//, and must be invalidated.
*This not only ensures that the State is held to strict account when it seeks to curtail individual liberties, but also guards against the //chilling effect// of broad and vaguely-worded laws -- that prompt people to engage in self-censorship in order to stay on the right side of the line.
<<<
----






----
;Reservoir Induced Seismicity
:The phenomenon of dam-triggered earthquakes is known as Reservoir Induced Seismicity. 
----
__Reservoir Induced Seismicity is not well-understood, but basically what happens is this__:

*When a dam is built and the reservoir filled with water, the amount of pressure exerted on the earth in that area changes dramatically. When the water level of a reservoir is raised, pressure on the underlying ground increases; when the water level is lowered, the pressure decreases. This fluctuation can stress the delicate balance between tectonic plates beneath the surface, possibly causing them to shift.
*Another factor is the water itself. When the water pressure increases, more of it is forced into the ground, filling cracks and crevices. All of this water pressure can expand those cracks and even create new, tiny ones in the rock, causing greater instability below ground. What's more, as the water sinks deeper, it can act as sort of a lubricant for rock plates that are being held in place by friction alone. The lubrication can cause those plates to slip.
''Koyna Deep Drilling project''

*A major national project involving deep drilling in the earthquake-prone Koyna intra-plate seismic zone in Maharashtra has been initiated by the central government for conducting scientific studies related to earthquakes -- international project to be led by Indian scientists -- the total cost of the project is Rs.472.3 crore for five years. 
*The proposed scientific deep drilling investigation in Koyna region will provide a unique opportunity to better understand the mechanism of reservoir-triggered earthquakes, developing a forecast model and assessing earthquake hazard in a stable continental region. 
*The main objective of the project is to undertake a deep borehole (6-8 kms) investigations in the Koyna-Warna region of Maharashtra where small and micro-earthquakes of varying magnitude have been occurring in a restricted area of 20 x 30 sq. km. for the past five decades, including the largest earthquake of magnitude 6.3 in December 1967. Past studies have clearly demonstrated that the Koyna-Warna area is a natural laboratory to study reservoir-triggered earthquakes, perhaps the best site anywhere in the world. 
*The project will also provide crucial insights into Deccan volcanism and mass extinction; thermal structure and state of stress in the lithosphere; geothermal potential of the West Coast Belt as well as the geothermal record of climate change in the region.






*[[Noyyal River]]

*''System of air quality forecasting and research'' -- computerised system jointly developed by Indian Institute of Tropical Metrology and IMD --
**Air quality prediction 48-72 hours
**Air quality index and UV index






*Sagar mala is an initiative floated by the Government of India to evolve a model of port led development which will transform India’s coastline as gateways of India’s prosperity.
*The concept of Sagar mala was first announced in 2003. However it didn’t take off. The concept has been reintroduced now and the Ministry of Shipping is the nodal point for implementing the project.
!!!Objectives
*The initiative aims at integrating three things -- the development of ports, industrial clusters and hinterland and efficient evacuation systems through road, rail, inland and coastal waterways. The Sagar mala initiative, therefore, focuses on:
**Modernisation of port infrastructure -- transforming the existing ports to world class ports and development of new ports.
**Efficient evacuation system by improving hinterland linkages through rail, road and water.
**Encouraging coastal economic development by promoting port based SEZs and ancillary industries.
!!!Strategy
*To realise the objectives of Sagar Mala, two broad strategies have been outlined -- development of coastal economic regions and promotion of coastal shipping.
**A ''coastal economic region'' will be identified as a region along the length of the state’s coast (300-500 km) and 10-30 km inland and into the sea. This is to widen the span of economic activity in the region. Sagar mala envisages formation of ten coastal economic regions along the coastline.
**Policy initiatives are also outlined for encouragement of coastal shipping by provision of green channel, incentives for use and simplification of procedures.
*Sagar mala initiative would encourage coastal shipping and inland waterways as main carriers of people and goods which is very essential to improve India’s sea borne traffic. With a coastline of 7,500 km, India’s seaborne traffic is only 950 million tonnes whereas China has a seaborne traffic of 9 billion tonnes with a coastline of 15,000km.
!!!Implementation
*A National Sagarmala Apex Committee (NSAC) is envisaged for overall policy guidance and high level coordination, and to review various aspects of planning and implementation under the chairmanship of the Minister of Shipping, with Cabinet Ministers from stakeholder Ministries and Chief Ministers/Ministers incharge of ports of maritime states as members.
*Sagarmala Coordination and Steering Committee (SCSC) will be constituted under the chairmanship of the Cabinet Secretary and with Secretaries of the respective stakeholder Ministries as members to provide coordination between various ministries, state governments and agencies connected with implementation and review the progress of implementation of the National Perspective Plan, Detailed Master Plans and projects. This Committee will also examine financing options available for the funding of projects, the possibility of public-private partnership in project financing/construction/ operation.
*At the Central level, Sagarmala Development Company (SDC) will be set up under the Companies Act, 1956 to assist the State level/zone level Special Purpose Vehicles (SPVs), as well as SPVs to be set up by the ports, with equity support for implementation of projects to be undertaken by them.






!!!Prelims
*
!!!Mains
*SC/ST -- Prevention of Atrocities Act
*Human Animal conflict -- reasons, challenges and solutions






!!!Background
*India's estimated tribal population is 100 million, if considered a nation by themselves, it will be the 13th largest nation.
*Tribals are mostly dependent on forests and have a close knit relationship with it.
*Tribal culture and lifestyle is mostly in form of sustenance-like minor forest produce, grazing grounds, water and jhum cultivation.
*The essential characteristics of these communities are their particular geographical location, distinct culture, economic backwardness(not in every case) and aloofness from the society at large
*The Permanent Settlement of 1757, the Forest act of 1865 and 1878 and the Forest policy of 1894 were one of the root causes of rebellions and revolts of the indigenous communities in India.
*In 1894, the Forest policy of India recognised forests as state property and rights of forest dwellers were severely curtailed and in some cses all human activities were banned
*British introduced a conept called "Scientific management of forests" that just foccused on commercialisation of forest procude(mostly timber, which resulted in encroachemnt of traditional rights of tribals
*The Forest Policy Resolution 1952 called for the protection of wildlife and preservation of fauna by demarcating the forests for sanctuaries and national parks. This culminated in the enactment of [[Wildlife Protection Act, 1972]].
*The National Forest Policy, 1988, made provisions to safeguard the customary rights and interests on forest land of tribals. 
*The 1988 Forest policy paved the way for implementation of the Joint Forest Management (JFM) which included the involvement of local village communities and voluntary agencies in the regeneration of the degraded forests.
*In order to implement these provisions, MoEF issued a set of six circulars on September 18, 1990 which decreed that pre-1980 occupation of forest land would be eligible for regularization provided the State Government had evolved certain eligibility criteria in accordance with the local needs and conditions.
*State govt failed to implement the guidelines and meanwhile on SC's order in 2003, under the act India Forest act 1927 and Wlidlife protect Act 1972, mass evictions were done by forest department which led to mass protest from tribal communities
*MoEF then released some guidelines in 2004 which was stayed by SC, later on Forest rights bill was placed in parliament
!!!Key Provisions
*Recognizes and vests forest rights in FDSTs (Forest Dwelling Scheduled Tribes), where they are scheduled, with respect to forest land and their habitat. The forest rights in the core areas of National Parks and Sanctuaries shall be granted on provisional basis for a period of five years from the date ofcommencement of this Act, in case they are not relocated within five years with due compensation, the rights would become permanent. The rights can be inherited but they are not transferable
*Delineates 12 rights of FDSTs over a variety of subjects. The rights include -- 
**Living in the forest for habitation or for self cultivation for livelihood, 
**Community rights such as nistar,by whatever name called, including those used in erstwhile Princely states, Zamindari or such intermediary regimes,
**Right to own, use or dispose of minor forest produce
**Conversion of forest village to revenue village
**Conversion of pattas or leases issued by any local authority or any state government on forest land to titles
**Other traditional customary rights. Customary rights exclude hunting, trapping or extracting body parts of any wild animal.
**FDSTs also cannot indulge in any activity that adversely affects wild animals, forests and the biodiversity in the local area and need to ensure that adjoining catchments areas and water sources are adequately protected.
*No FDST shall be evicted from forest land till the recognition and verification procedure is completed.
*The rights would be restricted to the area under actual occupation and shall not exceed an area of 2.5 hectares per nuclear family. The title would be registered jointly in case of married persons and in the name of the single head in case of single member households.
*The Gram Sabha is empowered to initiate the process of determining the extent of forest rights that may be given to each eligible individual or family.It would then pass a resolution to that effect and forward a copy to the Sub-Divisional Level Committee (SDLC) 
*The SDLC, which shall be constituted by the State Government, would examine the resolution passed by the Gram Sabha and prepare the record of forest rights, then forward it to DLC, which will be the final authority for approval
*A State Level Monitoring Committee would be formed to monitor the process of recognition and vesting of forest rights. The Committee would submit returns and reports to the nodal agency (the ministry dealing with Tribal Affairs)
*The SDLC, DLC and the State Level Monitoring Committee would consist of officers from the departments of Revenue, Forest and Tribal Affairs at the appropriate level as may be prescribed. 
*In case person is not satisfied with Gram sabha's ruling ,he can go to SDLC till DLC, and DLC's decion will be final and binding.
*In case person is found guilty of contravening or abeting the contravention of the act, will be fine and in case of repetitive offence, his rights will be derecognised by DLC for such period as recommended by gram sabha
*Provision of fine for authorities and members and officers in case they commit an offence.
*As per the Act, “forest villages” means the settlements which have been established inside the forests by the forest department of any State Government for forestry operations or which were converted into forest villages through the forest reservation process and includes forest settlement villages, fixed demand holdings,  all types of taungya settlements, by whatever name called, for such villages and includes lands for cultivation and other uses, permitted by the Government
*A Revenue Village is a small administrative region in India, with defined borders, that is recognized by the District Administration. One revenue village may contain many hamlets.
!!!Issues and Challenges in the implementation of this act
*Lack of data -- there are no reliable estimates of the number of families, or the number of FDSTs residing within the core areas of national parks and sanctuaries. Therefore, it is not possible to calculate how much forest land would be required
*Making the tough choice of doing injustice to tribal people by evicting them from their traditional lands or harming species of the forests by allowing human intervention
*Land ceiling may lead to further impoverishment of tribal communities and also, it will reduce legal cover of forest land there by leading to encroachment
*No specification as to what kind of evidence need to produced by FDSTs, this vagueness will ultimately hurt the FDSTs. Since tribes mostly have been living isolated from civilizations, they are less likely to have the kind of evidences like ownership papers or lease papers which are accepted in the court of law
*Other communities who depend on the forest for survival and livelihood reasons, but are not forest dwellers or Scheduled Tribes, for instance in large sections of Chattisgarh and forest tracts of Uttaranchal, are excluded from the purview of the Bill. This could lead to large-scale eviction of such people and increase social tension among the various forest communities. 
*Some tribes are nomadic and do not settle at one place; narrow definition of FDSTs can result in denial of rights
*No explicit restriction on the kind of tactics used for relocating FDSTs, history has enough examples of use of brutal force and violence 
*The act provides no clarification on the type of compensation will be offered to relocated FDSTs or what recourse they have if they are not satisfied with the compensation
*Certain terms have not been defined or adequately defined like
**FDST -- does not include the non-tribal forest dependent community
**Community forest resource -- is not defined, and hence, it is not clear whether these also include resources within government owned forests including National Parks and Sanctuaries.
**Nuclear Family -- Tribal families are different than modern families, so this term remains open for all kinds of interpretation
*No respite from judgement of DLC for FDSTs even of they are not satisfied with the ruling.
*There have been cases of forging Gram Sabhas rulings, for e.g. in Keojhar Odisha and Hasdeo Arand in Chattisgarh, and the fines for such offences are not deterrent enough.
!!!Forest Rights Act rules, 2012
*FDSTs get the rights like the right to collect and sell minor forest produce and the right to live in the forest land for habitation or self-cultivation for livelihood

*The Forest Rights Committee (FRC) of the Gram Sabha shall not reexamine recognised forest rights or interfere in the verification of claims that are pending
*The collection of minor forest produce is to be free of all fees
*The Gram Sabha shall monitor the committee constituted for the protection of wildlife, forest and biodiversity. It has to approve all decisions of the committee pertaining to the issue of transit permits to transport minor forest produce, use of income from sale of produce, or modification of management plans.
*This committee has to prepare a conservation and management plan for community forest resources. 
*‘Bonafide livelihood needs’ refers to the fulfillment of livelihood needs (earlier sustenance needs). These can be fulfilled through the sale of surplus produce.
*Community rights includes rights such as 
**Ownership, access to collect, use and dispose of minor forest produce, 
**Fishing and grazing, and 
**Conversion of all forest villages into revenue villages
*‘Disposal of minor forest produce’ includes individual or collective processing and storage by the Scheduled Tribes. The produce can be transported through appropriate means of transport (earlier transportation was only permissible by head-loads, bicycle and handcarts)
!!!Solutions
*GoI should clarify that Minor Forest Produce will not come under PESA( panchayati Raj extension to scheduled areas, and will apply to all scheduled tribes and not just scheduled areas, so that other FDSTs will also reap livelihood from MFP
*Silviculture practices (for MFP) should encourage crown forestry( products that are obtained from crown of the tree, i.e. leaves and branches at the top of the tree like mahua, tobacco) which provides regular crop rather than trunk based forestry in which it takes time for produce(timber) to mature (sal, teak etc)
*MFPs should also be sold in open markets so that tribals can get more avenues to earn more profit.
*Community forest rights should not be confused with development activites happening on forest lands like local schools or anganwadis, both should be kept separate as CFR is a specific right of the indigenous community.
*Separate Tribal census should be undertaken especially of FDSTs and other forest communities so that correct number of beneficiaries can be known
*FDST definition along with ST, should include all non-tribal forest dwelling/dependent communities and communities on the fringe of forests.
*More deterrents like heavier fines and penalities should be placed for offences ( forging gram sabha rulings, using brute force) by officers and authorities
*Specific studies should be done for specific core areas to know which core area can handle human habitation and which shoould be vacated to mitigate collateral damage
*FDSTs should be allowed to challenge the ruling of DLC to State Level Monitoring Committee
*Denotified tribes(tribes denotified from Criminal Tribes Act 1871, but still come under Habitual Offender Act since 1959) should be given their due rights; most of them are pastoral or nomadic so they should be given grazing lands under CFR.
----
<<<
''Note''

*Mahatma Gandhi coined the term "Girijan" or children of forest god for indigenous people.
*The Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers (Recognition of Forest Rights) Act, 2006 is also popularly known as The Forest Ricghts Act, 2006.
<<<
----






*The Securities Laws (Amendment) Act, 2014 (SLAA) was introduced in the backdrop of the shortcomings in the law identified during the recent investigations involving [[collective investment schemes|Collective Investment Schemes]].
*The SLAA was aimed at providing SEBI with additional investigative and sanctioning powers to enable SEBI to fulfill its role and purpose as an effective securities market regulator.
!!!Salient features of the Act
*The new law gave SEBI the power to search and obtain information, including call records, about any suspected entity from within or outside the firm. However, before conducting such searches SEBI must obtain a warrant from a Mumbai court.
*Any unregistered scheme with a capital of more than a ₹100 crore was deemed as a [[collective investment schemes|Collective Investment Schemes]], allowing SEBI to regulate it.
*The minimum penalty for securities related crimes was set at ₹1 lakh. The minimum penalty for [[insider trading|Insider trading]] was at ₹10 lakh.
*SEBI was given the authority to initiate recovery and sale of assets (disgorgement).
*SEBI has also been given the power to enhance a penalty or settle an ongoing legal proceeding.
*Guidelines for special courts were also included in the bill.






<<<
;Section 124A
:penalizes exciting //disaffection// against the government established by law, or bringing it into //hatred// or //contempt// -- allows for __life imprisonment in case of conviction__.
<<<

!!!Pre-Independence evolution of the Sedition provision
*Such a provision as absent from the original Indian Penal Code, 1860 -- Section 124A (Sedition) was inserted in the 1870s to thwart the growing Wahabi movement.
*Section 124A used the term //disaffection// -- i.e. acts or speeches that provoked individuals to disobey the government -- cleverly, the Indian nationalists exploited this loophole to deliver provocative speeches with no mention of //disobedience// -- in response, the British added the words //hatred// and //contempt// to Section 124A.
!!!Post-Independence evolution of Sedition provision
*Surprisingly, the Fundamental Rights Sub-Committee of the Constituent Assembly expressly included this Colonial era tool (Sedition) as grounds for restricting free speech in its first draft of the fundamental rights.
*The Assembly objected strongly and when [Ar.19(1)(a)] finally came into being, ''sedition'' was not among the permissible restrictions under [Ar.19(2)].
*Immediately after the Constitution came into being, the Supreme Court struck down government restrictions upon two magazines.
*To reconcile with the Supreme Court ruling, the first Parliament amended [Ar.19(2)] substantially, broadening its scope by including //public order// among the permissible grounds of restriction of free speech, while also narrowing its operation by adding the word //reasonable// before //restrictions//.
*Despite vociferous debates in the public domain to remove the sedition provision as quickly as possible -- Parliament took no action in that direction, and thus, the challenge was deliberated in the courts -- and in a landmark judgement in the Kedar Nath Singh vs State of Bihar, 1962 case, five judges of the Supreme Court upheld sedition as constitutional.
----
<<<
*The Supreme Court considered two views regarding Section 124A prevalent in pre-Independence India --
*#''Sedition'' was determined simply by the content of the language used, and whether it was such as to cause //disaffection//, //hatred// or //contempt//.
*#The other view, borrowing from English common law -- saw ''sedition'' as a crime against //public order//.
*The Constitutionality of Section 124A was determined by the Supreme Court by --
*#Holding the view that Section 124A may be used by the State as a reasonable restriction to the freedom of expression under [Ar.19(2)] -- only if the seditious expression could provoke a //public order// problem. Anything else was exempt.
*#Observing that the phrase -- //reasonable restrictions . . . in the interests of . . .  public order// -- under [Ar.19(2)] was particularly broad to accomodate Section 124A -- in order to allow the State to restrict expression detrimental to //public order//.
*The above line of thought broadly conforms to John Stuart Mill's famous //harm principle//, which suggests that the only justification for curbing a person's expression against his will is to prevent him from causing harm to others.
*However, with the Supreme Court reading into Section 124A a phrase that was absent initially i.e. //public order//, the provisions under Section 124A became ''over-broad'' -- because Section 124A, while proscribing some forms of expression, can also be used to curb Constitutionally protected forms of expression.
*Such a wide ambit has led Section 124A in being the most abused provision of the Indian Penal Code, since it can be conveniently invoked against anyone who disagrees or criticises the State's viewpoint.
<<<
----
*However, subsequent judgements, understanding the importance of free speech and the misuse that arises when trusting the State with too much power, have replaced the //public order// provision with a much tighter //incitement// requirement as below --
**Mr. Rangarajan, a film producer in Chennai (then Madras), was fighting for his right to release ''Ore Oru Gramathile'', a movie that criticized the caste-based reservation policy in Tamil Nadu’s educational institutions -- there was violent reactions and in response the Tamil Nadu government had stopped the film’s release, fearing “very serious” law and order problems across the state -- In the S. Rangarajan vs. P. Jagjivan Ram case, the Supreme Court insisted that it was obligatory on the State to protect the freedom of expression and that, the relationship between speech and disorder be like that of a //spark in a powder keg//.
**In the Shreya Singhal case, the Supreme Court noted the difference between //advocacy// and //incitement// -- and held that punishment consistent with [Ar.19(2)] was only for the latter.
!!!Way Forward
*At the moment, the possibility of the Supreme Court setting up a Constitutional bench to re-examine the Kedar Nath Singh case seems remote.
*Until such a review, it will be upto lawyers to demonstate how frivolous the sedition complaint is, and the lower judiciary to entertain only such cases that meet the Supreme Court's //incitement// requirement.
*Currently the [[Law Commission]] is preparing a report on the issue -- it must be seen how law makers react to it's recommendations.
----
''Note''

*In the U.K., laws on seditious libel and criminal defamation were summarily abolished in 2009
----
!!!Latest Developments
*Both Arundhati Roy (for a speech in Kashmir), Hardik Patel (Patidar reservation agitation)  and Kanhaiya Kumar (JNU issue) have been booked under Section 124A of the Indian Penal Code.
*Government’s admission in Parliament that the present definition of //sedition// in the Indian Penal Code is too wide and requires reconsideration -- and an All Party meet would be held to discuss the //sedition issue// after the [[Law Commission]] submits its report on the same.






<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/O_Caf7Gz4Es" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

''What are Driveless cars?''

*An autonomous car, also known as a uncrewed vehicle, driverless car, self-driving car and robotic car, is an autonomous vehicle capable of fulfilling the main transportation capabilities of a traditional car. As an autonomous vehicle, it is capable of sensing its environment and navigating without human input. Robotic cars exist mainly as prototypes and demonstration systems.
*Several manufacturers have announced their intention to roll out vehicles by 2020 with self-driving modes that fully operate the car in certain scenarios, such as highway cruising or stop-and-go traffic. Over time, self-driving modes could handle more situations with less human intervention, and declining costs might allow the technology to spread from luxury cars to the mainstream.
*As with any technological change, there will be winners and losers. Safer highways and lower fatalities will benefit all, though if collisions are reduced it will mean less work for body shops and tow trucks, and a declining role for insurance companies. More car-sharing would reduce the need for car dealers who principally handle retail sales. Full self-driving vehicles may eliminate cab-drivers, bus-drivers, or even truck-drivers if large vehicles are automated. Some of those jobs will remain but require a different skill set.
''How do Driverless cars work?''

*Driverless cars use a variety of tools analogous to those of a human driver. Instead of eyes and mirrors, an autonomous system uses an array of sensors to interpret surroundings and decide whether to accelerate, slow down, or change lanes e.g. Google's system relies upon a roof-mounted laser radar, or "lidar", system that scans the immediate environment and builds a three-dimensional map of its surroundings. Actuators and drive-by-wire systems allow the computer to physically control the vehicle in place of human hands and feet. Whether the car is electric or a traditional gas combustion engine is irrelevant; a well-designed autonomous system could control either. 
*While automated systems have the advantage of a constant 360 degree perspective unaffected by fatigue or inattention, today's systems are not as adept as humans in dealing with unusual circumstances, such as a policeman directing traffic or snowfall that obscures road markings. Because of these limitations, the autonomous vehicles of 2020 will likely self-drive only under certain conditions and relinquish control to a human driver if situations change.
*Also, the performance of even limited self-driving systems will need to be near perfect to gain acceptance of consumers and regulators.
''What are the potential benefits of Driverless cars?''

*Reduced crash fatalities -- more than 1.2 million people die globally each year due to motor vehicle accidents -- of which a great percentage is attributed to fatigue, drunkenness, inattention, and speeding -- which autonomous systems could eliminate.
*Experts say that some public benefits are only possible with the wide adoption of autonomous vehicles. For instance, autonomous vehicles could travel close together in high-speed platoons, effectively boosting the capacity of the nation's highways and improving fuel efficiency by cutting down air drag.
*As autonomous driving systems evolve and require less human supervision, the average morning commute of 25.5 minutes could become a productive time to catch up on email or hold a conference call.
*In the more distant future, fully driverless cars could bring new independence to owners who are blind or infirm.
''What are the risks associated with Driverless cars?''

*Even if most accidents are avoided, there will still be some, and likely a few that could have been avoided with an expert human driver at the wheel. Creating a legal framework to give reasonable safeguards and guidance to automakers will be critical for widespread adoption.
*Meanwhile, ethicists and lawmakers face thorny questions about potential liability and how to program vehicles to make split-second decisions. Problematic scenarios include whether a vehicle should swerve to avoid a certain crash if swerving could cause a collision with another vehicle, or if a traffic law should be broken to prevent an accident.
*Autonomous driving systems would also create new security and privacy concerns. Could someone remotely hijack your vehicle? Could police track where and when you car has been? One way around these concerns would be to not use vehicle communication, whether to another vehicle or to a centralized system, but some experts see this as unlikely given the many advantages of vehicle communication.
''Is the concept of Driverless cars suitable in the Indian scenario?''

*India’s needs could differ from the West which makes it important for companies here to develop their own driverless system and a disruptive innovation in the process.
*At least 13 people die every hour in road accidents in our country where over speeding accounts for more than 50 per cent of cases.
*The Planning Commission report by BK Chaturvedi estimates road accidents to cost roughly $20 billion annually. This is despite the fact that India has only one per cent of the world’s vehicles.
*__Pros in the Indian Scenario__

**As a result, planners in India can get cars to merge in cooperative patterns and, hopefully, put an end to snarls. Traffic intersections can be reworked with the hope that every car on the road will comply with the rules. Traffic lights could also become scarce thanks to hidden sensors in cars and streets. Cities of the future could have narrower streets and cleaner air, with no need for parking spots.
**A child old enough to ride a bicycle could be the right candidate to take a driverless car trip. The elderly and handicapped can also use it to go places. In terms of traffic policing, so long as a car is controlled by a driver, it needs to be operated manually.
**The more it is run by a computer, the easier it becomes to password-protect the car’s security system. This makes it a lot harder to steal unoccupied cars.
**Buying, insuring and maintaining a car is expensive for the Indian consumer. Driverless cars of the future would be the best source of sharing schemes, smart taxi firms and affordable leasing options.
**The design of roads and traffic are built around human needs which means lots of road signs, lane markers and street lights. All this only increases government spending. Speed limits can be safely raised when cars are driven with machine predictability.
*__Cons in the Indian Scenario__

**May be too costly to afford
**Requires a change in habits and there may be reluctance to trust machine predictability
**Requires great expenditure and time for R&D and design of such automative systems for Indian conditions
**Suitable changes in law required to define liability in cases of an accident due to automative systems






----
<<<
*The ''Serious Fraud Investigation Office'' (SFIO) is a statutory (Clause 211 of the Companies Act, 2013) multi-disciplinary organization under the Ministry of Corporate Affairs for detecting and prosecuting or recommending for prosecution white-collar crimes/frauds.
*The Government approved setting up of this organization on 9 January 2003 on the basis of the recommendations made by the Naresh Chandra Committee on corporate governance.
*The SFIO is involved in major fraud probes and is the co-ordinating agency with the Income Tax and CBI.
<<<
----
__The SFIO normally takes up for investigation only such cases, which are characterized by__:

*Complexity and having inter-departmental and multi-disciplinary ramifications ;
*Substantial involvement of public interest to be judged by size, either in terms of monetary misappropriation or in terms of persons affected; and
*The possibility of investigation leading to or contributing towards a clear improvement in systems, laws or procedures.
''Composition''

*SFIO shall be headed by a Director (appointed by a Central government notification, who shall be an officer not below the rank of a Joint Secretary to the Government of India having knowledge and experience in dealing with matters relating to corporate affairs).
*It will also consist of such number of experts from various fields like (i) banking; (ii) corporate affairs (iii) taxation (iv) forensic audit (v) capital market (vi) information technology (vii) law.






!!!Benefits
*Saves time and reduces cost of election (2014 was the costliest election so far with expenditure amounting to approx Rs 30000 crore).
*Requires same number of staff as for any election which implies less staff is required.
*Saves the campaigning cost met by contestants. Thus reducing the corruption.
*Encourages proper exercise of franchise as there will be no chance of missing either of the election.
*Helps in reducing defection.
*Helps in avoiding the Model Code of Conduct often restricting the free functioning of governments at the time of polls.
*Reveals the true majority of a party to form the government.
*Establishes stable government with balance of power in ruling as well as in opposition party.
*Ensures proper representation of all states in both the houses.
*Requires modernized EVMs and other voting methods thus fostering the technological advancements of the country.
!!!Disadvantages
*Some state governments have to sacrifice their terms mid way.
*Practically not possible because governments may even fall within a year after coming to power.
*People may tend to vote for a popular leader at centre forgetting the local governance, leading to poor governance in states.






*Small Saving schemes have been always an important source of household savings in India.
*Small savings instruments can be classified under three heads --
**Postal deposits
**Savings certificates e.g. National Small Savings Certificate and [[Kisan Vikas Patra]]
**Social security schemes e.g. [[Public Provident Fund]], [[Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana]] and Senior Citizens' Savings Scheme
!!!National Small Savings Fund
*A ''National Small Savings Fund'' (NSSF) has been established in the [[Public Account of India]].
*All small savings collections (withdrawals) are credited to (are made out of the accumulations in) this Fund -- the balance in the Fund is invested in Central and State Government Securities (to finance the fiscal deficit).
*The NSSF is also permitted to invest in securities issued by IIFCL.
*Since NSSF operates in the [[public account|Public Account of India]], its transactions do not impact the fiscal deficit of the Centre directly. As an instrument in the public account, the balances under NSSF are direct liabilities and constitute a part of the outstanding liabilities of the Centre.
----
<<<
*The income of NSSF comprises of the interest receipts on the investments in Central, State Government and other securities.
*The expenditure of NSSF comprises interest payments to the subscribers of Small Savings and PPF Schemes and the cost of operating the schemes, also called management cost.
<<<
----
!!!Connection between Small Saving Schemes and Monetary Policy
*The RBI has reduced rates by 125 basis points to a four-and-a-half-year low of 6.75 per cent while banks have transmitted only up to 70 bps in their base rate -- thus there is an impediment in monetary policy transmission.
*Banks argue that because high rates on small savings schemes -- banks’ fixed deposits are uncompetitive and in turn do not allow banks to reduce the cost of funds i.e. the lending rate.
!!!Recent Developments
*From the year 2012-13, the interest rates on various Small Savings Schemes (SSS), were being recalculated and notified in the month of March every year. This was being done in line with the recommendations of the Shyamala Gopinath Committee to ensure that the interest rates of Small Savings Schemes are market linked.
*On 16th February, 2016, it was notified by the Government that instead of annual resetting of interest rates for the upcoming financial year, the interest rates would be reset every quarter based on the G-Sec yields of the previous three months.
*Based on the above notification the Government reduced the interest rates on all Small Saving Schemes except the Postal Savings Deposit which is maintained at 4% -- this is being done to make small saving interest rates more market aligned.
''See also''

*[[Monetary policy transmission]]

*The Indian Societies Registration Act of 1860 was enacted under the British Raj in India, but is largely still in force in India today. It provides for the registration of literary, scientific and charitable societies (like NGOs).
*Under the Act societies may be formed, by way of a memorandum of association (MOA), by any seven or more people associated for any literary, scientific or charitable purpose. The memorandum of association has to be filed with the Registrar of Societies.
*The memorandum has to contain the name of the society, its objects (goals), and the names, addresses and occupations of the members of the governing body, by whatever name it may be called, duly signed for consent by all the members forming the society.
*A copy of the rules and regulations (RR) of the society also has to be filed along with the memorandum of association.
*Each state has its own Society Registration Act, for example BCCI is registered under the Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Act. So was Greenpeace India until it’s registration was cancelled in 2015 under allegations of fraudulent dealings.






<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xKxrkht7CpY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>






*A Solar Photovoltaic (PV) system employs solar panels composed of a number of [[solar cells|Solar Cells]] to supply usable solar power by means of [[photovoltaics|Photovoltaics]]. The [[Direct Current]] is then converted to [[Alternating Current]], usually with the use of inverters, in order to be distributed on the power network.
*Installations may be ground-mounted (and sometimes integrated with farming and grazing) or built into the roof or walls of a building (either building-integrated photovoltaics or simply rooftop).

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/k3CSg6gkU0E" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen style="width:100%;height:420px;"/>

!!!Benefits
*The direct conversion of sunlight to electricity occurs without any moving parts or environmental emissions during operation.
*Driven by advances in technology and increases in manufacturing scale and sophistication, the cost of photovoltaics has declined steadily and the levelised cost of electricity from PV is competitive with conventional electricity sources.
*Net metering and financial incentives, such as preferential feed-in tariffs for solar-generated electricity, have supported solar PV installations in many countries.
----
<<<
''Note''

*Solar PV is now, after [[hydro|Hydroelectric Power]] and [[wind power|Wind Power]], the third most important renewable energy source in terms of globally installed capacity.
*In 2014, worldwide installed PV capacity increased to at least 177 gigawatts (GW), sufficient to supply 1 percent of global electricity demands.
*China, followed by Japan and the United States, is the fastest growing market, while Germany remains the world's largest producer, with solar contributing about 7 percent to its annual domestic electricity consumption.
<<<
----






<<<
;Solar energy
:is radiant light and heat from the Sun harnessed using a range of ever-evolving technologies such as solar heating, photovoltaics, solar thermal energy, solar architecture and artificial photosynthesis.
<<<
!!!Classification
*Solar energy is an important source of renewable energy and its technologies are broadly characterized as either [[passive solar|Passive Solar]] or [[active solar|Active Solar]] depending on the way they capture and distribute solar energy or convert it into solar power.
''See also''

*[[Solar Power in India]]






*India is a tropical country and therefore, has enormous possibilities of tapping solar energy.
*As can be seen by the map below, the western part of India has greater potential for the development of solar energy in Gujarat and Rajasthan.
| !Solar insolation recieved across India (kWh/sq.m) |
| [img[http://www.solarmango.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/India_Solar_Map.png]] |

*India is fit for solar power generation given that the country receives solar radiation of 5 to 7 (kWh) per sq. m for 300-330 days in a year.
*In India, which is the biggest greenhouse gas emitter after the US and China, renewable energy currently accounts for only 13%, or 36,471 MW of India’s total installed power capacity of 2,75,912MW.
!!!Benefits of Solar Energy
*In rural areas electricity as an off grid solution
*Will minimise the dependence of rural households on firewood and dung cakes, which in turn will contribute to environmental conservation and adequate supply of manure in agriculture.
*Solar energy is 7 per cent more effective than coal or oil based plants and 10 per cent more effective than nuclear plants.
*Solar thermal technology has some relative advantages over all other non-renewable energy sources. It is cost competitive, environment friendly and easy to construct.
!!!Components of India's Solar Energy Policy
''Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission''

!!!Objective
*The objective of the Mission is to create a policy and regulatory environment which  provides a predictable  incentive structure that enables rapid and large-scale capital  investment  in  solar  energy  applications  and  encourages  technical  innovation  and  lowering of costs.
*The immediate aim is to focus on setting up an enabling environment for solar technology penetration in the country both at a centralized and decentralized level.
!!!Targets
*The Mission under the aegis of Ministry of New and Renewable Energy will adopt a 3-phase approach -- to initially achieve a solar power generation target was 20,000 megawatts (MW) by 2022 -- which was subsequently raised to 100,000 MW.
!!!Strategy
''Adoption of Solar Energy''

*Renewable Purchase Obligation mandated for power utilities -- will contain a specific solar component. This will drive utility scale power generation, whether solar PV or solar thermal. The Solar  Purchase Obligation will be gradually increased while the tariff fixed for Solar power  purchase will decline over time.
*The Central  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission has also  stipulated  that  Power  Purchase  Agreement  that  utilities  will  conclude  with  Solar  power promoters, should be for a period of 25 years.
*Capital subsidies of 15% -- applicable to rooftop solar power plants, up to a maximum of 500 kW.
*The new Model Building By-laws released recently mandates new buildings to have solar roof-top power generation.
''Research and Development''

*The R&D strategy will focus on --
**Improving  efficiency  in  existing  applications
**Reducing  costs  of  Balance  of  Systems
**Testing  hybrid  co-generation
**Addressing  constraints  of  variability,  space-intensity and lack of convenient and cost-effective storage
!!!WTO Dispute on Domestic Content Requirements
*Phase one of India's National Solar Mission is composed of two parts --
**Batch 1 -- India required developers of solar photovoltaic (“PV”) projects employing crystalline silicon technology to use solar modules manufactured in India.
**Batch 2 -- India expanded this domestic sourcing requirement to crystalline silicon solar cells as well.
*Following such domestic content requirements enabled solar project developers to take advantage of such benefits, including subsidies and guaranteed long-term competitive rates for solar power.
*In this Phase -- the government exempted thin film solar cells (lower efficiency solar panels used in large-scale industrial solar projects) from the domestic content rules because of low domestic capacity to manufacture such cells.
*This loophole created an opening for foreign countries, including the United States and China, to export thin-film cells to India.
*The U.S. exports of thin film solar cells to India have been particularly successful due to low interest loans from the U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank. Due to this US is having dominancy in thin-film panels in Indian market.
*To correct this imbalance and protect India’s solar manufacturers, India is now considering expanding the use of domestic content rules to thin film technologies in the second phase of its program, which may curtail imports of US solar panels to India.
*US was concerned about the impact on its export, due to the potential expansion of India’s domestic content rules (purchase a designated amount of locally sourced materials for projects) on thin-film technologies.
*The United States (US) has filed a case at the World Trade Organization (WTO) to challenge India’s use of subsidies and “buy local” rules in its domestic solar program, the Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission (JNNSM).
----
<<<
''Note''

*WTO members are not supposed to insist on national content requirements that discriminate against foreign products. Governments are also required to provide “national” treatment, under which imports must be treated on a par with domestically manufactured products.
<<<
----
''US Claim''

*As per the US trade Representative -- the domestic content requirements discriminate against US exports by requiring solar power developers to use Indian-manufactured equipment instead of US equipment. These unfair requirements are against WTO rules, and they will defend the rights of American workers and businesses.
*The phase II domestic content requirements have been expanded to cover thin film technology, which was exempt from such requirements under phase I (As thin film currently comprises the majority of US solar product exports to India).
''India’s defence''

*India claims that it has not discriminated against the foreign suppliers. The mission guidelines clearly mention that 375 mw out of 750 mw in the Phase II of the mission is open for bidding for projects using imported thin films.
*India also mentioned that two of the major US producers of thin films have got export credits from the US government, which is encouraging an inflow of older technology into India. US is dumping its low grade products to India, and was also charging more than the actual production cost.
*India also pointed out that US is also following the same policy domestically. There are about 13 US states having schemes that offer preference to purchase of power produced by US made solar products.






*A Sovereign Wealth Fund is a state-ownde fund or entity that is commonly established from balance of payments surpluses, excess foreign currency reserves, the proceeds of privatisations, government transfer payments, fiscal surpluses and receipts resulting from resource exports.
*Sovereign wealth funds can be characterized as maximizing long-term return.
!!!Common Sovereign Wealth Fund objectives
*Protect and Stabilize the budget and economy from excess volatality in revenues/exports.
*Diversify from non-renewable commodity exports.
*Earn greater returns than on foreign exchange reserves.
*Assist monetary authorities dissipate unwanted liquidity.
*Increase savings for future generations.
*Fund social and economic development.
*Sustainable long term growth for target countries.
!!!Recent Developments
*The world’s sovereign-wealth funds together have assets of $7.2 trillion, according to the Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute, which studies them.
*For years, sovereign-wealth funds—financial vehicles owned by governments—swelled in size and number, fueled by rising oil prices and leaders’ aspirations to increase economic growth, invest abroad and boost political influence.
*Now, some funds are shrinking or are being tapped by governments as commodity revenues fall. That is forcing them to borrow or sell investments, potentially pressuring global markets just as other investors are pulling back from risk.
*The International Forum of Sovereign Wealth Funds, an industry body, has pushed members to adopt a code of conduct known as the ''Santiago Principles'' which calls for annual reporting, clear governance rules and effective risk management, among other things. The code is voluntary, however. At least five of the 29 forum members don’t publish public annual reports. At least four don’t disclose their asset size.
!!!Top Sovereign Wealth Funds
#Norway’s Government Pension Fund Global
#Abu Dhabi Investment Authority
#SAMA Foreign Holdings
#China Investment Corporation
#Kuwait Investment Authority
#Hong Kong’s SAFE Investment Company
#Hong Kong Exchange Fund
#Government of Singapore Investment Corporation
#Qatar Investment Authority
#China’s National Social Security Fund
